story:
An overview of the project: 

  1. These funds go directly toward the production and exhibition of a photo essay exploring these issues and the people in my life whose experiences go untold and unheard every day. This project is one facet of my undergraduate thesis for the honors program at Arizona State University. Your support is crucial to the success of this project. I appreciate every single click, share, and donation. Thank you.

  2. This venture explicitly aims to honor Larry's life and legacy, establishing a sustained conversation about navigating the intersections of gender, sexuality, race, class, and youth. In addition, this project can give back to LGBTQIAP youth in a material way, opening the door for further opportunities for self-discovery. 

  3. Claiming perks to the right of the page is the best method to fund my thesis and get a beautiful piece of art or thank you along the way.


Communication - Connection - Community 

On February 12, 2008, Lawrence “Larry” King – a friend and fellow student at E.O. Green Middle School in Oxnard, California, where I attended – was murdered in an isolated hate crime by another student, Brandon McInerney.  Brandon was eventually convicted of killing Larry for being LGBT and gender non-conforming. In plain view of an entire classroom of eighth grade students, the drama played out across local and national news, including such media as The Ellen DeGeneres Show and The Advocate, which ran a cover story about the incident. I now view this particular happening as the moment that most profoundly changed the course of my life - the singular event that pushed me to confront myself as a queer teenager in an environment hostile and unwelcoming toward Otherness, from peers and administration alike.

Sexuality and gender identity, however, are not singular events. 

They are complex, layered, and unique to each individual. 

I want to honor this individuality and celebrate the lives of the queer, trans, nonbinary, asexual, and other beautiful friends who fill my life with radical joy. 

By centering the lives of queer and trans individuals - especially queer and trans women of color - I seek to amplify voices and narratives that might otherwise go unheard or become misconstrued through sensationalized media.

For a long period after the shooting I retreated into myself, using photography as a tool to project my trauma and investigate what it meant to be young, queer, and confused. With this project I will attempt to explore the development of my unique embodied identity - particularly in regard to my own burgeoning sexual identity as a preteen - from an intersectional framework rooted in feminist ideologies. Through this process I will investigate Larry’s death as an important facet within a broader cultural dialogue surrounding queerness, transmisogyny, and sexuality-based bullying within school systems. I will also explore the intersection of race, gender, and class that informs Larry’s situated identity and the rhetoric surrounding the shooting.

I am fascinated by photography's ability to illuminate seemingly mundane or ordinary scenarios, locations, and individuals and  gain a deeper understanding of people’s livelihoods and the political underpinnings of their embodied experiences. This project utilizes photography as a medium for reclaiming the turbulent spaces and places that helped shape these queer identities, including my own.  

I took many photos after the shooting and gained a deeper understanding of myself, including the spaces and places in which I spent much of my adolescent life. However, a photo essay depicting the current state of my community and chosen family of queer, trans, and other LGBTQIA friends doesn't exist yet. This is where your contributions enter the frame. I want to return to Ventura County to complete an unfinished narrative and supplement this journey by documenting the lived experiences of my friends in Arizona and New York. 

Photo by Eunice Beck, 2015

  • Bam! Here's a total breakdown of my projected costs for this summer's travels and exhibition in the fall, including unforeseen costs and shipping materials for perks like envelopes, bubble mailers, and stamps. 
  • If my entire goal is not reach, funds will be reallocated accordingly and the exhibition will be made smaller. However, when we reach 100% of the goal a full-scale exhibition for the public is totally possible! 

What's in it for you? Perks! Claiming perks to the right of the page is the best method to fund my thesis and get a beautiful piece of art or thank you along the way. Photos of painting prints will be up shortly!
  • This is the opportunity to go behind-the-scenes and get a peek at the inner workings of my project. From limited-edition prints to original outtakes, you have the opportunity to invest in pieces that would not see the light of day if not for your contributions and support. 
  • From original paintings to prints and more, there is bound to be something that strikes a chord in you. 
  • Don't see a perk you like? Email me and we can work on creating a new one for everyone to enjoy or crafting a one-of-a-kind experience just for you!

Yours Alone, 2008

  • This project explores gender and sexual identity through the lens of an important event that has gone largely ignored and unnoticed by both mainstream media and queer activists alike. An exhibition to take place during the Fall 2015 semester at ASU, will bring knowledge and insight into the shooting, its impact, and the voices and stories of trans and queer youth who experience(d) school-based violence on a daily basis.
  • With these funds I will be able to successfully carry out the latter half of my undergraduate thesis, a requirement for my honors certification and graduation. My thesis defense is slated for mid-October 2015.
  • I will be presenting my thesis research at the National Women's Studies Association Conference in Milwaukee, Wisconsin in November 2015. The visual component and complement to my traditional research goes beyond a traditional academic paper and I want to share it with other writers, activists, and thinkers. 

Nova, 2008 

There are many potential risks involved with this project, many that will occur if this campaign does not receive enough support throughout and beyond its run.

  • When we reach 100% of our goal, I have set aside $200 for any unforeseen costs that may occur along the trip, such as extra food or public transport costs (I plan to use the subway system in New York), as well as other emergency expenses. 
  • This project is all about community, and thankfully I am privileged to have a close-knit group of family and friends who will help regardless. However, this project will be an uphill struggle if we do not rally enough support.  You can help eliminate risks and challenges by donating and, most importantly, getting the word out! Check out how to lend your voice below. 

Hueneme Beach, 2008


The best way to keep this campaign going is to share it with your circle of family, friends, and members of your community! 
  • Share this campaign on your social media feeds by using the link http://igg.me/at/youbelongtome.
  • Facebook? Tumblr? Twitter? Share this project! Strike up a dialogue with friends and continue the conversation beyond this page. 
  • Use the hashtag #YBTMproject when sharing, or send me an email if you get some great feedback! 
  • If you have any questions or comments, feel free to email me at brandonmarks@asu.edu. 

Thank you so much!

story:
Napier Photo Collective is a group of BA (HONS) Photography graduates of Edinburgh Napier University. The class of 2014 will be participating in Free Range 2014 in London this June. Free Range is one of Europe’s biggest graduate shows with over 100 0000 visitors in 2013.

We are a photo collective consisting of national and international students who have studied together for the past 4 years. We have successfully exhibited as a group before and are looking forward to our degree show in Edinburgh in May. We want to keep the ball rolling and decided to take our work down to London in order to show it to an even bigger audience alongside other universities. This is a great chance for us to get our work exhibited and meet fellow students and industry professionals throughout the UK. We do all of this on our own initiative and welcome every bit of support.

In order to achieve this we need to raise £ 3000 to cover our expenses for

Transport (we are traveling from Scotland)
Wall rental (the space is already paid for, but we need to construct walls)
Consumables and 
Promotional Material We already covered the creation of our work with our individual funds and secured support through sponsors and our university. We will also hold a special event (TBA)  to which we would like to welcome you with some refreshments. 

Please feel free to have a look at our work on our website and follow us on our other social media channels. This is a great opportunity for you to acquire unique work by an ambitious group of up and coming photographers. We hope you will enjoy our work and the special perks we will offer for your support. You can also help us out a lot by sharing our campaign on social networks.

Links to all of our work can be found below!

Our exhibition dates are:

Thursday June 12th - Monday June 16th

Opening Night
Thursday 12th at 6pm -10pm

Opening Times
Friday 13th - Sunday 16th 10am 7pm
Monday 16th 10am- 4pm


http://napiercollective.tumblr.com/

story:
*the campaign thumbnail was my only attempt at taking a nice family photo and above is a sampling of my work

 

Hello there!

As a young family, it's not always easy taking great pictures together. Our 1-year old makes it crazy difficult to take a family picture à la tripod and self-timer. Hence, we have hundreds of sweet photos of just my wife and son or me and our son, but not many of all three of us...looking at the camera at the same time. I'm also a photographer (on the side) so you can imagine the frustration of not being able to beautifully capture this amazing time in our lives.

That said, I'd like to offer some photo shoots to help fund our dream portrait session with our favorite (way pricey) photographer so that my family will have at least one set of decent photos together to remember this awesome, tiresome, frenzied, love-filled time as a new family.

 

What's In A Photo Sesh?

My stuff: djanzanophoto.tumblr.com

SF Bay Area locals only please. An engagement, couple, or family portrait session includes:

  • 1 - 2 hours of shooting
  • 20 - 30 edited hi-res images on disk

 

Full disclosure: This definitely isn't a charity and there are way more worthwhile and noble causes out there (like donating to foster youth or supporting an animal rescue) but if you're diggin' my photography, would like to help us fund our dream photo shoot AND help me build my portfolio that would be rad!

Thanks and cheers!

story:
India GoGo - A Photographic Journey

In 2013, I traveled solo to Maha Kumbh Mela, the largest human festival on Earth, and took photos of the sadhus and pilgrims (holy men & women) with my iPhone4. A few months later, in the apple orchard village of Old Manali, I was discovered as a photographer. 

My passion is to return to India, immerse myself in the festivals and rituals, travel with the sadhus, live simply in the villages, and photograph along the way — this time with professional equipment! 

Couple in a Cart, 2013

My Photography Story

From the time I got my iPhone4, I was taking photos; mostly of my son at first, then of everything I found interesting, beautiful, and unique. I took photos often, but I did not consider myself a photographer. In India, I took thousands of photos, enthralled by the colors & contrasts of the culture. While sharing my collection to a group of travelers, one dear man convinced me - actually transmitted a message to me  -
"I was a photographer".

Upon my return to California, I, with the help of my son, Calvin, learned how to download photos from my iPhone, edit in Lightroom, print and frame. Within weeks, I had my first photography exhibit I HEARD HER CALLING, which led to several other exhibits.

My next step was to research cameras. After much investigation and a few trips to the camera shops, I bought my first digital camera, a Fuji X-E1.

Sadhu in the Light, 2013

My Photography Career

Now that I had a camera, I had to learn how to use it! I photographed every event, fundraiser, band, and festival around the Los Angeles area. In my hometown of Topanga, California, I photographed the Topanga Film Festival, Topanga Days Country Fair, Topanga Earth Day, Chili Cook-Off and Swap Meet, Reggae on the Mountain, Topanga Folk Fest, and Topanga Artist Studio Tour. Before long, I was working with Topanga Messenger covering the Topanga Nutcracker and other local stories.

   

    

     

I photographed over 150 bands - blues, jazz, rock, reggae, and folk. Several of my photographs were published and many bands started using my photos for their websites and promotions.

  

   

   

And soon after, I photographed my first magazine cover and two double-page spreads!

    

I photographed the Hare Krishna Festival of Chariots in Venice Beach, Bhakti Fest in Joshua Tree, Leimert Park Village African Arts & Music Festival, the Chumash Powwow & Intertribal Gathering in Malibu, and a Hollywood Red Carpet event for the film Miles Away.

   

      

One of my photos was chosen for the book Sacred Pregnancy

   

... and my photo GRATITUDE AND GRAVY FOR ALL was chosen as editor's pick for National Geographic's assignment The Story of Hunger and Hope, and acclaimed chef Mario Batali will be using my photo for his upcoming book FEEDING AMERICA: Stories of Hunger and Hope.

       

My Photographic Journey

Here's the tentative itinerary of my photographic journey. I will be flying into Mumbai the first week of November. I will take some days to acclimate to the weather, prepare my gear, and purchase a train ticket to Ajmer, and then onto Pushkar. 

November 14-25, 2015 ~ I having been dreaming about going to the Pushkar Camel Fair. I will settle in town early and photograph the desert worn traders as they arrive with their camels and carts. The festival will evolve into spectacle and carnival, culminating on the full moon, with pilgrims bathing in the holy lake.

December/January ~ I am yearning to visit the fishing villages along the Arabian Sea, and possibly travel as far south as Kerala.

January 14-April 22, 2016 ~ Ardh Kumbh Mela in Haridwar. I am excited to experience ceremonies with the sadhus among the millions who travel to this holy festival. 

March/April ~ I will celebrate Maha Shivaratri on March 8th, and Holi on March 23rd along the Ganges River, with travel to Varanasi and Rishikesh. As India's temperature rises, I will ascend to the hill stations of Manali and Dharamshala, and finally into the sacred Parvati Valley.

I joyously anticipate sharing these images with you. It is with your contributions that will make my photographic adventure possible. Thank you for participating in this journey with me!

Contributions

Your contribution will support me in fulfilling my passion of returning to India and photographing the sadhus (holy men & women), the villagers, the festivals, and the everyday life of India.

Contributions will go towards the following categories:     

Transportation - Three flights, trains, buses, tuk tuks & bike rental

Accommodations - Two months of festival season and four months village living

Meals - This category includes meals and simple daily supplies

Equipment - I will be purchasing an additional camera body, a prime lens, several batteries, SD cards, an external hard drive, and a tripod

Campaign Costs - Production and shipping costs for perks, plus indiegogo and banking fees

Contributions over campaign amount will go towards equipment and supplies, printing & framing for upcoming photography exhibits, and initial production of photography book.

Shivaratri Boys, 2013

Perks

Your contributions are greatly appreciated and will make this journey happen! The perks listed here are tokens of gratitude. All contributions include a subscription to my travel blog FOREVER AND A DEJA ~ Follow me as I explore and photograph India. Enjoy! 

All shipping in the United States is included; please check with us for shipping costs outside of the United States.

Photo Session Perks

$250 ~ Lifestyle Photo Session ~ Individuals, families, children, couples, friends, pets ~ up to 2 hours in Los Angeles area. I am available to travel to your area – travel expenses additional.

$500 ~ Event Photo Session ~ Parties, gatherings, celebrations, reunions, fundraisers, special events ~ up to 6 hours in Los Angeles area. I am available to travel to your area – travel expenses additional.

$1,000 ~ I Love India Photo Session ~ Come join me in India for 1-5 days on my journey and I will photograph you in an amazing scenario in India.

$1,200 ~ Catered Indian Dinner & Photo Session ~ Join me for a catered Indian dinner for you and 6 of your friends at a beautiful Topanga location with a sunset photo session. I am available to travel to your area – travel expenses additional.

Book Perks

$25 ~ Photography E-Book ~ You will receive I HEARD HER CALLING E-Book, a compilation of photos and writings from my 2013 journey in India. 

$100 ~ Photography Book ~ You will receive I HEARD HER CALLING Book, a compilation of photos and writings from my 2013 journey in India. 

Photographic Journey Perks

From my upcoming PHOTOGRAPHIC JOURNEY, I will compile and send you a PRIVATE portfolio of 20 or more photos. Choose your favorite image(s).

$250 ~ You will receive ONE medium to large size print. 

$450 ~ You will receive TWO medium to large size prints. 

$800 ~ You will receive FOUR medium to large size prints. 

Gallery Perks

$5 ~ Wallpapers  
$50 ~ Art Magnet Sadhu in the Light
$350 ~ Custom Framed Sadhu in the Light


Sadhu in the Light

$75 ~ 12x12 Framed Exhibit Print

  

  

Motorbike Babas, Blue Turban, Sadhu Looking In

$150 ~Medium Framed Exhibit Print

       

    Family in Village Market, Cell Phone Sadhu, White Hair Sage 
Shivaratri Boys, Women at Sangam

$200 ~ Large Framed Exhibit Print

    Varanasi Swordswoman, Black Turban

Other Ways You Can Contribute - SHARING

All contributions are appreciated. You can contribute by SHARING my story with your friends and letting the world know about India GoGo - A Photographic Journey. 

A few ways you can SHARE:

  • Forward my India GoGo campaign correspondence to your friends and family via your email lists and social media community
  • Copy the campaign URL and paste it into an email or social media update
  • Click on the Facebook, Google Plus or Twitter icons to share through your social media networks
  • Add a widget to your blog or personal website. Click Embed and then copy and paste the widget code.
  • If you need technical assistance in SHARING this campaign, contact us.

Thank you for contributing!

Women at Sangam, 2013

Accommodations - Two months of festival season and four months village living
Meals - This category includes meals and simple daily supplies
Equipment - I will be purchasing an additional camera body, a prime lens, several batteries, SD cards, an external hard drive, and a tripod
Campaign Costs - Production and shipping costs for perks, plus indiegogo and banking fees
Contributions over campaign amount will go towards equipment and supplies, printing & framing for upcoming photography exhibits, and initial production of photography book.




Shivaratri Boys, 2013
Perks

Your contributions are greatly appreciated and will make this journey happen! The perks listed here are tokens of gratitude. All contributions include a subscription to my travel blog FOREVER AND A DEJA ~ Follow me as I explore and photograph India. Enjoy! 
All shipping in the United States is included; please check with us for shipping costs outside of the United States.


Photo Session Perks


$250 ~ Lifestyle Photo Session ~ Individuals, families, children, couples, friends, pets ~ up to 2 hours in Los Angeles area. I am available to travel to your area – travel expenses additional.
$500 ~ Event Photo Session ~ Parties, gatherings, celebrations, reunions, fundraisers, special events ~ up to 6 hours in Los Angeles area. I am available to travel to your area – travel expenses additional.
$1,000 ~ I Love India Photo Session ~ Come join me in India for 1-5 days on my journey and I will photograph you in an amazing scenario in India.
$1,200 ~ Catered Indian Dinner & Photo Session ~ Join me for a catered Indian dinner for you and 6 of your friends at a beautiful Topanga location with a sunset photo session. I am available to travel to your area – travel expenses additional.
Book Perks
$25 ~ Photography E-Book ~ You will receive I HEARD HER CALLING E-Book, a compilation of photos and writings from my 2013 journey in India. 

$100 ~ Photography Book ~ You will receive I HEARD HER CALLING Book, a compilation of photos and writings from my 2013 journey in India. 
Photographic Journey Perks

From my upcoming PHOTOGRAPHIC JOURNEY, I will compile and send you a PRIVATE portfolio of 20 or more photos. Choose your favorite image(s).
$250 ~ You will receive ONE medium to large size print. 
$450 ~ You will receive TWO medium to large size prints. 
$800 ~ You will receive FOUR medium to large size prints. 
Gallery Perks


$5 ~ Wallpapers  

$50 ~ Art Magnet Sadhu in the Light

$350 ~ Custom Framed Sadhu in the Light



Sadhu in the Light

$75 ~ 12x12 Framed Exhibit Print

  

  

Motorbike Babas, Blue Turban, Sadhu Looking In


$150 ~Medium Framed Exhibit Print


       
    Family in Village Market, Cell Phone Sadhu, White Hair Sage Shivaratri Boys, Women at Sangam$200 ~ Large Framed Exhibit Print


    Varanasi Swordswoman, Black TurbanOther Ways You Can Contribute - SHARING

All contributions are appreciated. You can contribute by SHARING my story with your friends and letting the world know about India GoGo - A Photographic Journey. 
A few ways you can SHARE:

Forward my India GoGo campaign correspondence to your friends and family via your email lists and social media community
Copy the campaign URL and paste it into an email or social media update
Click on the Facebook, Google Plus or Twitter icons to share through your social media networks
Add a widget to your blog or personal website. Click Embed and then copy and paste the widget code.


If you need technical assistance in SHARING this campaign, contact us.



Thank you for contributing!



Women at Sangam, 2013

story:
Get Your Picture on the Billboard!

Latest version!


Original version -

The Ark Encounter is a water park based on a representation of Noah’s Ark. They are receiving state tax incentives while maintaining their discriminatory hiring practices. Scheduled to open in Williamstown, Kentucky on July 7, 2016, the park celebrates a biblical parable of genocide and incest. While they have a legal right to celebrate their mythology, we find it immoral and highly inappropriate as family entertainment. Help us remind the surrounding community and potential patrons that the biblical story of Noah’s Ark is immoral and should not be encouraged as a family fun day. 

Goals

  • REACHED! $10,000 – With our new mobile billboard, we have raised enough to drive our billboard around the Ark Encounter every weekend for the entire summer!

  • $15,000 –  Organize a protest in front of the Ark Encounter on their opening day and one kick-ass after party celebrating science and reason with comedians, live music, speakers and possibly a debate!

  • $30,000 – Fly a plane over the Ark Encounter opening weekend with a 125 foot banner displaying “Genocide and Incest Park”

  • $150,000,000 - we will build our very own Genocide & Incest Park and ask for state tax incentives and we will not discriminate during hire

They are portraying the story of Noah's Ark as an actual historical event.  This is scientifically not possible. Help us raise awareness to this immoral story! Genocide is not a reason to celebrate. Incest is not a reason to profit.  When this amusement park opens to entertain children and celebrate genocide and incest, we want to spread awareness by placing our billboards in as many locations as possible. 

All funds raised will be used to bring awareness through billboards, social media, etc. Any excess funds will be used to throw our own celebration promoting science and reason on their opening day.

Note: Donations can be made anonymously. Choose to hide your name when you make a donation. 

About Tri-State Freethinkers

Tri-State Freethinkers is a social, academic, and activist group with over 1,300 members in Kentucky, Indiana, and Ohio. We are advocates for equal rights and the separation of church and state. We empower our members to make positive change by giving back to our community. We make our decisions based on facts, logic and reason, not superstitions, myths, or dogma.

The Tri-State Freethinkers are a 501(c)(3) non-profit. Your donations are tax-deductible.

Help make this a reality! 

Other Ways to Help

Visit our website: http://www.tri-statefreethinkers.com

Join us on Meetup: http://www.meetup.com/Tri-State-Freethinkers/

Follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TriStateThinkers

story:
The Désiré project

This is a project that I have been working on for several months. It began with my archiving older photographic images, filing them and generally organizing all the images I have taken over the past 20 years. As I was reviewing all of these photographs, it occurred to me that some of the images that I had previously decided not to use, either due to accidental camera shake or double exposure, had very strong compositional value to them. Coincidentally, at the same time that I was going through my old photographs, I had been researching historical Albumen printing process for possible use in printing my still life images. The still life photographs all include antique tin type portraits, and researching alternative and longstanding methods of printing seemed fitting.  Then an idea came to me.

I started by creating a digital negative a la’ Dan Burkholder, with whom I had the pleasure of working back in 1996. After creating the negative and outputting via Lightjet onto clear film, I sent the new experiment to a NYC lab that I knew still did alternative processes. 

I was very impressed with the result! In June of 2012 I finished my selection process, choosing the previously discarded images that now shine in this new series. I realized that due to the cost, technical complexity and size limitations that are part of the Albumen process, it may not be the best way to go, but I wanted to maintain the aesthetic of the Albumen printing process as they complemented the images superbly. I would like to publish this new series in a limited edition photographic book.

Why I need your help

The funds raised via Indiegogo will allow me to complete, print and publish a third book of photography based solely on these rediscovered images. Please note that this is a second fundraiser for this project, as the goal was not reached in the initial pitch.

This collection of the newly created Desire’ series will be produced as a limited edition, 26 page 8” x 10” hardcover photographic book printed on real archival quality photographic silver-halide paper.  

 
Please visit http://www.santerineross.com/page23/Rewards.html  to view the images available for the rewards listed to the right.

story:
"What is this s***?"

I've been an avid amateur photographer focusing in scenic, landscape, and macrophotography since 2011.  I'm entirely self-funded and self-taught, and I feel that my pride in my output is justified.  On my own, I've sharpened my practical skills quite a bit through dozens of photo shoots, both formal and spur-of-the-moment, and have done a lot of self-study to increase my theoretical knowledge.  I've increased the capabilities of my equipment several times.  Photography may be the only thing I've maintained a true passion for in my adult life.

But there's still a lot of room to improve.  I've got specific, attainable goals to do just that.

This year I'd like to push my skills much further, with an eventual goal of becoming professional-grade.  The major obstacle to that, like with anything worthwhile in life, is funding.

Why I'm harassing you for money:

My biggest goal for this spring is to attend a professional development seminar in Salt Lake City, run by photographers from National Geographic.  (Details can be found at the URL below.)  This incurs a significant amount of travel expense, the admission for the seminar itself, and a hotel stay for the time of the seminar.

Last summer, I took an ad hoc photo retreat to southern Utah, a spectacularly scenic high-desert region with a number of state and national parks. I got some great photos (two of which are used on this page) and learned a lot.  I plan to do this again, combining such a trip with the seminar.  The location, centered around St. George, Utah, is only around six hours away by car from Salt Lake.

Finally, I'd like to improve my gear yet further.  I'm fully pleased with the capabilities of my Pentax K-30 digital SLR; however, my lenses leave a bit to be desired.  As lighter, plastic-bodied "kit" lenses, they're at the bottom end of the Pentax product line.  I have my eye, however, on lenses that're significantly nicer.  One of my main complaints during last year's photo retreat was "These are nice, but oh, what could have been?"  This would resolve that.  Pentax is known for keeping the same lens mount format for the entirety of their history, and current Pentax cameras have no problem mounting and utilizing the K-mount film SLR lenses from thirty years ago.  Therefore, an investment in quality lenses is going to be a lifelong resource even as I upgrade my camera bodies over time.

http://www.nationalgeographic.com/ngtseminars/seminars/nature-landscape.html

"What's in it for me?"

Check out the Perks section to the right!  I've got two four five MANY now, and will be brainstorming further perks to add.  I'm always up for suggestions as well!

Transparency:

I HATE asking people for money.  Like, really super extra hate it.  One of the only ways I can bring myself to do so is to be extra transparent and open about the circumstances under which I'm constrained, and share full detail on what I'd like to do.  So here's the full breakdown of why I'm asking for so much:

  • Admissions cost to the seminar: $199.
  • Rental car: $0.  I originally had planned $350 for a rental car, but have since changed my plan.  I'll be taking my personal vehicle for this trip.
  • Fuel: $500 (estimated).  The round trip to go from Seattle, to Salt Lake, to St George, and back to Seattle is a little over 2,300 miles, or 3,700 km.  At current fuel prices, that alone will run just over $300 in petrol. I've added another $200 to account for side trips to the various national parks and incidental driving for things like family visits.
  • Hotel for two nights in Salt Lake while at the seminar: $100 per night, or $200 total.
  • Hotel for five nights in St. George: $139 per night, or $695 total.
  • Pentax DA☆ 16-50mm f/2.8 wide-angle zoom lens: currently $820 on Amazon.  This is a near-direct replacement for my current DAL 18-55mm kit lens, but is very slightly wider angle and less zoom, and is much more capable in low light.  Since sunrises and sunsets are some of my most frequent photo shoots, this is important.  It will serve as my primary lens for scenic photography and is highly capable for general use as well.  Pentax's DA☆ line is one of their highest end offerings; only the DA Limited prime lenses are better.  Optical clarity, low-light performance, and image detail should be very significantly increased.
  • Pentax DA 55-300mm f/4-5.8 zoom telephoto lens: currently $450 on Amazon.  This is an exact, direct replacement for my current DAL 55-300 kit lens.  It offers no new capability, but is more sturdily constructed out of metal instead of plastic, and has higher quality optics and additional lens coatings for better image quality.
  • Pentax DFA 100mm f/2.8 macro lens: currently $560 on Amazon.  This doesn't replace any of my current gear, but offers significant new capability.  Macro lenses are optimized for very close focus and outstanding detail on small, detailed subjects such as insects.  I don't currently have a macro lens at all.  This isn't necessary for scenic or landscape photography, but is important to expand my work more fully into the several types of photography that I'm interested in.  Like the DA☆ lenses, the DFAs are a higher grade than the baseline DA or kit DAL lenses.
  • Fees: up to $480.  IndieGogo charges 4% fee for all donations received if a Flexible Funding campaign meets its funding goal, but 9% otherwise.  My expectations are not very high, so I anticipate 9%.  Additionally, credit card processors charge 3% transaction fees.  If this campaign misses its goal by only $1 (thus maximizing the 9% fee, and avoiding the 4%) then IndieGoGo will charge $359.91 and credit card processing $119.97, for a total of $479.88.
  • NOT included at all: costs for routine expenses such as food and park admissions.  These are relatively trivial and I'd feel bad asking for help with them.  This also includes small incidental equipment such as additional battery packs and lens cleaning supplies.
  • Combined total: $3,903.88 including fees.
I'm going to be perfectly honest -- I feel that this trip is fairly necessary to my ongoing sanity.  It's absolutely going to happen even if I don't get a single dollar of donations.  However, it'll be happening on a credit card, and $4000 will take me a rough guess of 6-7 months to pay back off.  Donations will make it much, much easier to do this without incurring so much debt.  I'm not expecting friends and family to absorb the cost of my trip so much as laying out all my expenditures so that anyone inclined to chip in can do so, fully informed.

The Impact:

With the additional skills I hope to acquire during the seminar, as well as four to five days of shooting afterward to exercise and solidify the knowledge, I feel confident that I will grow significantly as a photographer.  As you are all my audience, with my entire body of work freely available on Photobucket and Facebook, this means I fill your eyes with more and better eye candy.  

Eventually I hope to produce work of such a quality as to be employed as a photographer.  This is a good step along that path.

Risks & Challenges:

Risks for you, the potential contributor?  There aren't any, really.  The worst that could happen is that for some reason I don't make it to the seminar, and your money doesn't go towards it.  In that case, I will work with any contributors to offer a full refund of their money, including any fees taken by IndieGoGo or credit card processors.

Challenges for me?  Only the best kind: creative challenges.  It will be my job to learn from the seminar and to put that knowledge to work producing better art than I have at any point to date.

Thank you for reading all of this!

story:
Black Hills Powwow 2014 Sponsor Photographer

ThunderBird Eye Photography (Formerly Clarice Lakota Photographic Arts) has been a proud sponsor photographer for the Black Hills Powwow (He Sapa Wacipi) in 2012 and is returning to the Black Hills area this year in October 2014 to once again be a sponsor to the annual powwow held in Rapid City, South Dakota.   

This year the need is great for additional financial sponsorship to cover costs of equipment additions, travel, gas, insurance and lodging.  Prior years were completely covered and donated with the photographers own personal funds. Unfortunately this year's trip will require outside assistance. 

What your donation will do is to directly assist in covering the costs of the most basic necessities. This will allow the photographers to attend, photograph, interview, and travel to the 2014 Black Hills He Sapa Wacipi (Black Hills Powwow). It will also provide the funds to visit and photograph the Black Hills National Forest, Crazy Horse Memorial, Wounded Knee, and the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. 
  

Copies of my images obtained during the Black Hills Powwow are freely donated to the Black Hills Powwow Committee after final editing to use as they please over the following year(s) free of charge, and also allow them to keep a historical perspective on each event through the images and information.  

What We Need & What You Get

  • Thunderbird Eye Photography is seeking $3,000 to cover lodging, gasoline, insurance, new lens/filter, assistance, gratuity, meals, and traditional gifting items when appropriate for obtaining photographs and/or interviews over a 7 day period from October 8 through October 14, 2014. 
  • Donation $50 to 99 = Two 12" x 8"  Print Of Choice From BH Powwow 2012
  • Donation $100 to 149 = Two 16" x 12" Prints Of Choice From BH Powwow 2012
  • Donation $150 to 299 =  Two 24" x 16" Prints Of Choice From BH Powwow 2012
  • Donation $300 to 499 = Memory Card COPIES Of Final Edited Photographs From The Location of Choice - Powwow, Black Hills, Crazy Horse, Pine Ridge
  • Over $500 = Memory Card COPIES of ALL Final Edited Photographs From The South Dakota Trip (Of All Locations).  
  • If the goal of $3000 is met and/or exceeded, the remaining funds will be used for direct equipment upgrade of Nikon gear/products and/or any emergency costs incurred during said trip.
  • If the goal of $3000 is not met, all funds donated will be used for gasoline, lodging, and meals.  All above listed offers still apply whether the goal is met or not. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    You may not be able to contribute $$,  but that does not mean you cannot help!:

    • Please share the link to my campaign, that is a GREAT HELP! 
    • Be an advocate for ThunderBird Eye Photography's goals in 2014!
    • Let your voice be heard!

What We Need & What You Get
 
Thunderbird Eye Photography is seeking $3,000 to cover lodging, gasoline, insurance, new lens/filter, assistance, gratuity, meals, and traditional gifting items when appropriate for obtaining photographs and/or interviews over a 7 day period from October 8 through October 14, 2014.  Donation $50 to 99 = Two 12" x 8"  Print Of Choice From BH Powwow 2012
Donation $100 to 149 = Two 16" x 12" Prints Of Choice From BH Powwow 2012
Donation $150 to 299 =  Two 24" x 16" Prints Of Choice From BH Powwow 2012
Donation $300 to 499 = Memory Card COPIES Of Final Edited Photographs From The Location of Choice - Powwow, Black Hills, Crazy Horse, Pine Ridge
Over $500 = Memory Card COPIES of ALL Final Edited Photographs From The South Dakota Trip (Of All Locations).   If the goal of $3000 is met and/or exceeded, the remaining funds will be used for direct equipment upgrade of Nikon gear/products and/or any emergency costs incurred during said trip.
If the goal of $3000 is not met, all funds donated will be used for gasoline, lodging, and meals.  All above listed offers still apply whether the goal is met or not. 

  Other Ways You Can Help You may not be able to contribute $$,  but that does not mean you cannot help!: 
Please share the link to my campaign, that is a GREAT HELP!  Be an advocate for ThunderBird Eye Photography's goals in 2014!
Let your voice be heard!

story:
Short Summary

Yuri!!! on Ice on Ice would be a photoshoot and meet up at the Kettler Capitals Iceplex the Sunday of Otakon (8/13).  Otakon is the perfect opportunity as one of the biggest anime cons in the area means that there's a better opportunity to have a wide variety of cosplayers from the show meet up.  Having this meet up and photoshoot at an ice rink makes it even better since fans can show off their skills or learn to skate.

I have been cosplaying for a little over 3 years now and I have experience running photoshoots at Katsucon, Otakon, and Anime USA.  After being introduced to Yuri!!! on Ice by my friends, I knew I had to cosplay Viktor.  I completed my cosplay back in April and now I want to contribute to fandom even more by organizing this event.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The Kettler requires $450 to rent out an hour's worth of ice.  That $450 includes a Zamboni resurfacing and skate rentals.

Indiegogo's minimum campaign goal is $500, so the extra $50 can go towards any fees or taxes that might pop up.

Also, we have some stretch goals:

  1. $950- 2 Hours of Ice NO LONGER AN OPTION
    • Instead of renting the ice for an hour, we would get 2 hours- that's more time to socialize, practice skating, and make some cool photos!
  2. $1150- Hired Photographer EDIT: AT $750
    • In addition to 2 hours worth of ice,
    • for $200, we hire a photographer to take a pre-agreed number of photos that would only be for personal use or promotion (not for sale by anyone afterwards)
    • Photographers would be able to make a bid and all paying contributors would have the chance to vote for their favorite based on a portfolio sample

If we exceed funding but don't reach a stretch goal, then the leftover would go to the local LBGT+ based charity, Casa Ruby.

Benefits

Why not have this shoot at Katsucon?  Renting out the ice gives us a private setting so we're not competing with other skaters for space and allows a comfortable setting of like-minded people.  Renting out an indoor rink also has the advantage of good lighting and being more similar to the actual backdrops from the show.

Additionally, the perks for contributions are comparable with the regular skate and rental fees of the Kettler- $14 for adults.  A single admission for our event is $17 and each tier above that lowers the price per person which means this is a great deal.

Why the Kettler in particular?  The Kettler is home to DC's own hockey team, the Caps.  That means this is a high quality facility and decent sized ice rinks.  The location itself is also convenient since it is a five minute walk from the metro and also has a massive parking garage.  Once we're funded, I'll put out step by step instructions of how to get there just in case because the Kettler is, rather uniquely, on the roof of a mall.  There are plenty of signs on how to get there once inside the mall, but I'd hate for anyone to get delayed because they walked a block in the wrong direction or something.

Risks & Challenges

The only risk we face is this campaign not being funding.  Since this is an all or nothing campaign, if it doesn't get funded, then any contributions would return to the people who made them.  Once we are funded though, contributors will be given a poll on what time we want to start so it would be unlikely that someone would miss it.  The rink itself is metro accessible and has plenty of parking.

Anyone who would like to go, but does not want to contribute needs to reconsider.  The only real risk for our campaign is it not getting funded.  If it doesn't work out then you will get your money back.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not going to Otakon?

  • If you're local, you can join us anyway!  The ice rink rental is not part of Otakon, so it's fine if you're not going to the con.  Just remember to contribute!
  • If you're out of town, but would love to see this photoshoot happen anyway, please feel free to donate whatever amount you wish.  Anything is appreciated!
  • If you're a bit tight on cash at the moment, please get the word out as an alternative.  Letting people know helps make the event more inclusive and people who might not otherwise know can hear about it.  Besides, once Otakon rolls around, maybe things will be a little better and you'll be able to join us!

Who's Allowed to Go?

Everyone!

Cosplayers, photographers, and friends are all welcome.

After we're funded, a survey will be sent out and contributors will need to supply the names of attendees.  You'll be able to change these up until the morning of.  This will prevent people from joining who haven't paid or aren't spoken for.  It's not fair to make only some people pay.

The Setup

Here's how the meet up will be scheduled:

  1. Contributors will be sent a survey in advance to vote on the exact time we should meet on that Sunday.
  2. The first half-hour will serve as a time block for everyone to arrive, warmup, and socialize.  Friends and photographers not in cosplay can also use this time to skate
  3.  Then we'll have the Zamboni make the ice nice and smooth.  Everyone needs to arrive by this time too or else they'll risk being shut out.
  4. For the second half-hour, I ask that only Yuri!!! on Ice cosplayers and photographers skate who need to be on the ice.  This will allow for better and easier photos.

 

**Neither myself, the organizer, or the Kettler Iceplex are liable for any possible injuries.  By attending you accept this and are responsible to make your own choices when acting in potentially risky ways.  Minors need to be accompanied by someone over 18 years old (they will also need admission).**

story:
Who Is Randy Lemoine and Why Does He Need Me?

My name is Randy Lemoine and I am a cityscape/landscape photographer based out of New York City, USA. I have been actively shooting film and digital cameras for approximately 10 years and enjoy the process of taking a specific subject or idea and transforming that imagery into a pleasing photo people can enjoy. After being laid-off from a corporate IT job,  I have decided to fully pursue my dream of becoming a photographer. I have traveled to various locations such as Iceland, the Philippines and Death Valley capturing wonderous moments and experiencing new cultures.

Many of the images I have captured have gained recognition and awards. Recently, “West Side Story” received Honorable Mention in the International Photography Awards, while others have been featured in publications such as Audobon Magazine and Harvard Review.

Sadly, I have never actually had the ability to personally print any of my images in high-quality since I do not own a darkroom nor a professional-grade printer. Thus my reason for reaching out to potential supporters for help.

By supporting “The Print Project”, your funds enable me to acquire the necessary resources to achieve this goal; an Epson professional-grade printer. This will be the cornerstone piece for my company and fuel future projects such as gallery exhibits and fine art sales.

What’s Needed & How You’re Rewarded

So you’re probably wondering how much funding does a project like this require.  Well, considering the sizes I need to print and the avaliability of paper and ink, I will need approximately $2,000.00 to cover all costs of the equipment. This ensures a quality printer that will last and will produce superior quality images that will last for 100 years or more.

As a supporter, you benefit from perks such as museum-quality prints and image longevity that has been proven to last for 100+ years. You also have free-reign on choosing any print of your choice from my collection www.randylemoine.com. Just select which perk you would like to fund on the right and you’re golden. All prints will be signed by me personally and printed on exhibition-grade papers. Many of these prints are provided to you at a discounted rate, simply because you’re awesome.

If funds do not meet the target goal, then an alternate printer option will be considered at an alternate price (i.e. smaller print size, etc.).

Your Impression

Before you leave please consider the impact your support would make on an upcoming artist. I will be truly thankful and extremely happy that someone helped me achieve an important piece of a lifelong dream. Please feel free to message me or leave a comment if you have any questions.

Happy funding!

story:
Debra Casey was born in Hollywood, CA and moved to Maui, HI in 1996 and Honolulu in 2013. This vegan tattooed body piercer became a surfer and photographer and now shares her unique perspective of island life and other adventures.
ImagesByDebraCasey.com. 

I want to show a different side of the beauty of Hawaii in a book and an art show.  You can help me make this dream a reality! I believe this book would make a great addition to all of the mundane Hawaii photo books out there. I want to put it in Local Boutique hotel gift shops and eventually get national distribution.

story:
Spiegel der Seele (Mirrors of the soul)

Photography exhibition by Marco Pejrolo
With original texts by Sudabeh Mohafez and Alberto Salza
Original songs by Antun Opic

Gasteig - Munich 24th  January – 13th February 2017

www.spiegel.photos

The project wants to create a visual and  emotional bridge between the people portrayed in the photos and the exhibition visitors, by using the power of photography to do what is usually impossible every day: we are enveloped in our hectic lives - often superficial and distrustful - and we don't seem to be able to find the time for a deep visual contact. We are unable to listen while we are looking at something.
It's as simple as that.

I asked myself what role photography could have in what was happening around us. Today. In Germany, where I live. Reporting? Witnessing? Denouncing? I asked myself how a photographer could sympathize with the reality around us and so I tried to involve the viewer, to make him an active subject. The image itself wasn't enough, photography had to become a mirror.

In the mirror the subject becomes the object: contemplating itself, recognizing itself and identifying with it. It unveils itself. If you stand in front of your image a bit longer, the subject won't just be reflected but will start reflecting: thoughts, emotions, feelings will come up.
What if the surface weren't a mirror but another face in a photo?  The face of one of the unknown people who have dragged their existence up here, fleeing from the war and destruction? Could we spot anything about ourselves in that picture? About our past? Our identity? Is there a common trait between us and them that could let us see any thoughts, emotions, feelings?
People's eyes become mirrors where life and the soul can be reflected. Wide open eyes, smiling, noble, serious, hidden, innocent, distrustful eyes, where you can glimpse or imagine a glare of their existence or of ours.
The photography exhibition “Spiegel der Seele” suggests interaction between the viewer and the photographs on display. In each of them you will meet some eyes in front of which you can stop, like in front of a mirror, and wait until you can perceive the little part of you reflected by that look. Or you may see what is hidden within those eyes, in the depth of their light and write about it. Therefore, next to each photo on display there is a space where you can note down your impressions while contemplating the image: a collective album of thoughts and feelings that the snapshot will have aroused in the viewers.
This mirroring process will be accompanied by some texts written by the German writer Sudabeh Mohafez and by the Italian anthropologist Alberto Salza, each of them inspired by a portrait on display. Some original songs written and sung by Antun Opic will be the soundtrack of this visual and emotional experience.
The whole artistic production, including portraits, texts and songs, will be included in the exhibition catalogue.

What We Need & What You Get

If you choose a Perk including a Fine Art Print here are the pictures you can select to be printed:

By contributing to our project you will be joining us in a cultural event against racism and intolerance.
    15.000 € is our goal to enable us to print 200 catalogues, to produce the CD of the songs written by Antun Opic inspired by some portraits and to make our exhibition travel around the country. All funds will be used to cover the exhibition costs: producing the CD, printing the book, normal printing production expenses such as press proof sheets, distribution cost and other miscellaneous expenses. If we do not reach our entire goal of 15.000 €, whatever we raise will still go completely towards exhibition production.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We need your help.
Please take the time to share this site with friends and family. Your individual help can make a huge difference to the success of this project and is greatly appreciated.
We have been encouraged by the response and conversations we have already had with people involved in the project, people who take care of refugees and help them. So tell your friends, family and others about the exhibition and how they can help us.
Please share our story and this site on Facebook, Google+, Twitter, Pinterest, LinkedIn and any other social media you are comfortable with.
Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
Thank you!

More information about me and my work as a photographer:
www.marcopejrolo.com

story:
Rebekah Pascouau, founder and photographer of Rebekah Pascouau Photography, is launching this campaign to raise funds for the lighting equipment needed to build a basic studio setting and improve upon on-location shoots. The goal set at $1,500 covers the minimum amount of equipment needed to start the studio setup, as well as making the equipment usable outdoors with the necessary outdoor power pack. Not too many outdoor locations have wall sockets, after all!

Rewards range from $10 to $275 packages, including special deals on photo sessions*, art photography prints, and limited edition art books. These packages are discounted from the usual costs, with print and session rewards as much as 50% off the usual price!  

*PLEASE NOTE THAT PHOTO SESSIONS ARE AVAILABLE IN THE HAMPTON ROADS AREA OF VIRGINIA ONLY.

With the launch of this campaign, Rebekah will also be launching her new Facebook page and website. Be sure to like "Rebekah Pascouau Photography." on Facebook, and bookmark the website to stay up to date on her latest projects!

As always, thank you to all of my friends and clients for your support.
- Rebekah

Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/RebekahPascouauPhotography

Website: http://rebekahpascouauphotography.zenfolio.com

Below are just a few examples of prints you can order. Backers can choose ANY image under the following categories (BUT BE SURE TO ORDER THROUGH THE CAMPAIGN, AND NOT ORDER OFF THE WEBSITE, OR I WILL NOT RECEIVE FUNDING FOR THE PROJECT!):
- Portfolio: "Band Promos," "Live Shows," & "Art & Concept Photography" - Projects & Prints: "Let's Get Some Shoes," "Masked Society," "Body Image," & "Popular Prints for Sale"

- "The Kiss": From the "Art & Concept Photography" Album:  

- Andy of Combichrist: From the "Live Shows" Album:

"Kittens and Stripes": From the "Let's Get Some Shoes" Album:

 "Anonymous Pleasure": From the "Masked Society" Album:

"Bound in Love" OR "Love of Binding": From the "Popular Prints" Album:


RISKS AND CHALLANGES:

While there are no real risks for getting prints to a backer, there can be a few challenges with setting up a photo session. Here are some potential causes for delay: 
1. Some backers will want their session right away, while others may be interested in postponing the session to a later date. 
2. Scheduling can be difficult, and the level of difficulty increases with the number of people added to a photo session.

For each photo session reward, I have listed "November 2013" for the estimated delivery date. This campaign will be opened by the end of September and closed by the end of October. Because lighting equipment is really large/heavy/delicate, it can take a while to ship. Listing the date at October gives me a month to have the equipment shipped after ordering it. In this sense, the "delivery date" is more like a "start date": sessions can start as soon as I have the equipment.

Final risk: The estimated "delivery date" of photo sessions, as stated before, depends on the delivery date of the new equipment. If an essential item is back-ordered, backers with a photo session package will be notified immediately and updated on the expected time available to shoot.

Some backers will want their session right away, while others may be interested in postponing the session to a later date. 2. Scheduling can be difficult, and the level of difficulty increases with the number of people added to a photo session.
For each photo session reward, I have listed "November 2013" for the estimated delivery date. This campaign will be opened by the end of September and closed by the end of October. Because lighting equipment is really large/heavy/delicate, it can take a while to ship. Listing the date at October gives me a month to have the equipment shipped after ordering it. In this sense, the "delivery date" is more like a "start date": sessions can start as soon as I have the equipment.
Final risk: The estimated "delivery date" of photo sessions, as stated before, depends on the delivery date of the new equipment. If an essential item is back-ordered, backers with a photo session package will be notified immediately and updated on the expected time available to shoot.

story:
Our Story

Syndey Byrd (July 3, 1944) – is an artist, ethnographer and journalist who, over the past forty years, has devoted much of her life to documenting the culture and celebrations of Southern Louisiana in color photographs. Her work is distinguished by its scope of subject, graceful intimacy and seductive color. Nowhere are these characteristics more powerfully represented than in Byrd's images of the New Orleans region's remarkable Carnival season. And we are now trying to preserve these iconic pictures so that we can continue to enjoy the art she has created. 

 

As is true with many artists, Syndey has been working as a freelance photographer her entire life.  And now that she is reaching retirement, Syndey cannot get to all the events New Orleans offers that she loves to document .  Sadly, this is creates a poor financial situation for an incredibly talented artist.

The Impact

 

Having photographed so many New Orleans events for over 40 years, Syndey has understandably taken a  very large number of pictures during that time.  Her current archive is in a slide format and needs to be converted into digital so that we can preserve her excellent work.  Our goal once these archives are converted, is to set up a website for her where she can display and sell her work and also, help her earn an income. 
 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The contributions will go towards hard drives for storing the pictures, a slide scanner to convert the slides to a digital format, and paying assistants for their labor.  

You get a signed copy of any of the photos in this slideshow. You can choose a 8x10 or 16x20 print.

Syndey Byrd Collection for IndieGoGo

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We need help, lots of it. If there is any way you can help give us a shout.

Plese let others know about this campaign.

story:
Photographic Polar Expeditions

Life in the Extreme

Scott MacQuarrie

 

The polar regions are some of the most extreme environments on this planet. Yet life exists there. These regions are little understood and visited by few people. Life on land in Antarctica is almost non-existent with less than 2% of the continent not covered by ice. There are few creatures that can survive in these harsh conditions and most of them leave during the dark, cold Antarctic winter. Yet, life thrives in Antarctica, primarily in the ocean.

Antarctica is the coldest, windiest, driest, highest and most extreme continent on this planet. It has only been in the last 100 years or so that humans have had the technology to travel and explore Antarctica. It is still poorly understood even though it’s the subject of almost continuous study. It is Life in the Extreme.

I plan to join two polar photographic expeditions, the first to the Arctic in August and the second to Antarctica in November, with two objectives:

  1. To show these remote parts of the world and increase our understanding of them; and
  2. To show you through my work the visual experiences Antarctica and the Arctic provide and the intensity of experiencing them.

Both of these expeditions will involve ice-grade vessels with skilled and experienced crews, which should reduce the risks as much as possible. Both expeditions will be comprised of professional photographers and enthusiasts and the focus is on the creation of great work.

The Arctic expedition in August will leave from Svalbard, Norway above the Arctic Circle, cross to Greenland and travel south to Iceland. We won’t be below the Arctic Circle until reaching Iceland.

The Antarctic expedition in November will travel from Ushuaia, Argentina across the Drake Passage, 600 miles of the roughest ocean water in the world. We will also be transporting scientists to an Antarctic base and will be given the unique opportunity to visit and photograph there.

Each trip is an expensive undertaking. If I reach half of the required funds, I will go on the Arctic expedition. If I reach close to full funding, I will also go on the Antarctic expedition.

I have been to both Antarctica and Iceland. I am a professional photographer with over ten years experience, having won both national and international awards for my work. I am an X-Rite Coloratti, a voting member of the American Society of Media Photographers (ASMP), and have been awarded a Certified Professional Photographer (CPP) designation by the Professional Photographers of America (PPA). I invite you to see examples of my work at www.zwcx.com.

In early May the first US gallery exhibition of my work opens at the Avery Gallery, 390 Roswell Street, Marietta, Georgia 30060. The gallery has been very supportive of my work. Their website www.averygallery.com features some of my work that is being exhibited. I will be at the gallery May 3rd and 4th for the opening. If you can attend the opening I would be delighted to meet and talk with you.

I do need and welcome your support through the pre-purchase of my work. I am offering limited edition prints that will be printed entirely by me on my Epson 3800 and Epson 9900 printers to museum archival standards using some of the best fine art papers available from Moab paper and using Ultrachrome K3 inks. Each print will be signed and numbered by me on the front and back and will include a Certificate of Authenticity. Each print will ONLY be available in the sizes described as part of this campaign. With the exception of up to two Artist’s Proofs, I will create no other prints of these sizes for these photographs. Each of the limited edition prints will be shipped unframed in tubes (the smallest shipped flat) and will also include my recommendations for framing and framing materials.

If you choose to purchase any of my work described below I will pay the shipping and any applicable Canadian taxes, such as HST or GST.

I will be creating a special email list that I will update during the expeditions ahead of other sources. I will also be updating my blog, Facebook, Google+, and Twitter with activities before, during, and after the expeditions. The main purpose of these trips is to share the experience with others, so I’m going to do exactly that.

I am also going to donate 10% of the funds raised in this campaign to the David Suzuki Foundation where it will support a variety of climate and environmental initiatives. You find out more about the foundation at www.davidsuzuki.com.

I look forward to sharing the adventure of Life in the Extreme with you. 

Thank you very much for your support.

story:
Let's be fair, most of you reading this are familiar with C&Rsenal's flagship documentary series: Primer.  

Well we're trying to sell you a poster so you can put a piece of the show on your wall and, in the process, help fund the whole thing.  I won't lie; we planned this poorly and the costs are stacking up.  These days we've cleared equipment and transport, but we're down to trying to make custom ammo dies, custom sheet steel clips, repairing 100 year old gas systems, and the requisite therapy bills.

We're committed to using every cent to chase down as many of the pieces from the war as possible, going over each in fine detail for your education and entertainment.  Thanks, as always, for the support!

 

This Year's Poster:

 

 

Last Year's Poster

story:
THROUGH MY EYES

THROUGH MY EYES is a photography project designed to give children in rural Nicaragua an opportunity to express themselve through photography and encourage them to stay in school. Nicaragua is the second poorest country in Latin America; the average family lives on less than 10 US dollars a day, barely enough to put food on the table and a roof over their head.  16% of the population survives on less than 2 US dollars a day. Though most children enter the school system, many leave early to help their families financially. For the families, the long-term benefits of education hold much less value than the short-term financial benefits of children working to add to the family income. In its small way, THROUGH MY EYES is intended to address this reality.

Four young students in the Province of Rivas will each be given a camera to document their lives for a week. At the end of the week, the photos will be uploaded to a computer at which time the child and myself will select the photos that best document his/her daily life. Once all four children have selected their photos, they will be printed and presented in galleries across Nicaragua and the United States. As well, their school will be given a computer and the camera to integrate photography into their curriculum. A photo book of their work will be made available for sale through my website, http://paulschlindweinphotography.weebly.com. Half the proceeds from the sale of the photo book “THROUGH MY EYES” will be donated to the San Juan Del Sur Mobile Library Rural Schools Outreach Program which makes available books to rural school children who would otherwise have no access to them. The other half of the proceeds will be used to help fund more THROUGH MY EYES projects throughout Central America.

 

WHAT YOUR DONATION BUYS:

4 digital camera with memory cards and rechargeable batteries which will be donated to the children’s schools  [200ea]

4 computers which will also be donated to the children’s schools  [600ea]

4 printers and 4 reams of photo quality paper to print students’ photos will be donated to each school [200ea]

4 solar powered generators, one for each school [most rural schools do not have electricity, so to operate the computer a generator is necessary] [600ea]

A lesson outline for the teachers to integrate photography into their classes.

Logistical expenses- travel, photo printing and distribution

 

What you’ll get by donating:

First and foremost, you’ll have the knowledge that you helped a student find a means of expressing him/herself. Beyond that, you’ll know that a rural school in Nicaragua will have access to technology previously unavailable to them. More specifically, you’ll receive 2 5x7 prints of your choosing from the student’s work, 2 8x10 prints, a copy of the THROUGH MY EYES photo book, or a gallery-style canvas wall hanging of a student’s work.

 

Here’s how you can help:

Obiously, GIVE GIVE GIVE. Just as important, tell everyone you know to give too. If you’re wondering who “everyone” is, it’s your mother, your father, your siblings, your friends, your enemies, your boss, rich people, generous people, anyone and everyone! Seriously, spread the word!
Call them.
Text them.
Tweet them.

Post on your Facebook page.
And while you’re at it, ‘like’ us on Facebook.

 

ABOUT ME:

After 25 years as a television photojournalist [aka cameraman] I relocated to South America. While I continued to work sporadically in the television industry, I took up photography as a second career.

Throughout my journeys through Latin America I was struck by the desire to learn of the school aged children despite having even the most basic educational tools.

When I lived in San Francisco, I created and taught a media arts discipline at the School of the Arts High School. Students were taught the basics of video and film production and were offered the opportunity to create personal video projects. What started as a program for 12 students blossomed into a program of 30 with dozens more on the waiting list. It was evident that these children were starving for a way to express themselves. This experience was the germ of the idea behind THROUGH MY EYES.

 

REWARDS:

$10- a 4x6 print of your choosing

$25- a 5x7 print of your choosing

$50- an 8x10 print of your choosing or 2 5x7 prints

$100- 2 8x10 prints of your choosing

$500- a 10x14 ready-to-hang mounted-print of your choice

$1000- a 16x20 canvas mounted-photo with gallery-wrapped edges ready to hang.

story:
My name is Claudia D. Hernández. I was born and raised in Guatemala. I am a bilingual educator in the city of Los Angeles and I am currently finishing a Masters in Multicultural Education at Dominguez Hills. I am also pursuing an MFA in creative writing at Antioch University Los Angeles. My photography, poetry, and short stories have been published in The Indigenous Sovereignty Issue of The Peak, Hinchas de Poesía, Poets Responding to SB1070, La Bloga, KUIKATL Literary Journal, nineteen-sixty-nine an Ethnic Studies Journal, Blood Lotus, REDzine, Kalyani Magazine, Along the River II Anthology, among others.

I've had numerous photography exhibits throughout California including: “The Waiting Compendium” at the South Gate Art Gallery, South Gate, CA; “Renuncia” at El Sereno Gallery, El Sereno, CA; “Renuncia” at Corazón del Pueblo, Boyle Heights, CA; “Concrete Reality” at the Play House, Long Beach, CA;  “My Chapina Roots” at the YogArt Show, Whittier, CA; “Capturing Life” for Operation Smile fundraiser at the Museum of Latin American Art (MOLAA), Long Beach, CA; "Frontera: De mi lado" photography exhibit for Proyecto Esperanza fundraiser at the Museum of Latin American Art (MOLAA), Long Beach, CA; and “The Rhythm of Landscape” at the Sun Rise Poetry Series, San Francisco’s Mission District, Ca.

On March 2012, I took part in the 5th Annual ‘Día de la Mujer' exhibition in San Ysidro, Ca.
 
PROJECT:

I seek to curate a photography exhibit for the young girls in my community. It is my objective to photograph STRONG / SUCCESSFUL / REVOLUTIONARY women who will inspire these young girls to follow their dreams and to become who they want to be. I want young girls to learn how to recognize and overcome oppression whether it comes from government institutions, family members, or friends.

My desire is to raise awareness by planting the seeds of empowerment in the minds of young girls.

The money raised through this campaign will allow me to share these photos with my community and the world. I will also publish a book that will be given as a GIFT to every woman who attends the exhibit.

Since I will be publishing this book on my own, I have decided to work with a team consisting of an Art editor who will do the layout of the book and a book editor who will work editing the stories of resilience of each revolutionary woman. Together, we will work to produce a book and an exhibition that will not only inform, but also inspire young women to overcome any obstacle they experience throughout their lives.

 

EXPENSES:

Book designer -$2,000

Book Editor - $2,000

Print 150 books  $5000

(given as a GIFT to each young

girl who attends the event.)  

Traveling expenses  $3,000 

Exhibit/reception expenses $1,000

30 Frames $1,500  

Photo prints $300    

Mail photo pieces and books to artists $500     

TOTAL =$15,300

 

Goal – Fees = Your Take-away
$16,500 - Fees = $15,345

 

If I don't reach my entire goal, the funds will go to publishing the books and paying the editors. I will find other means to raise funds for the exhibit and pay for my traveling expenses.

THE IMPACT

My project is valuable to my community and the world because I will photograph women of color who are still alive making a difference in this world with their art, activism, and love.

I have contacted approximately thirtyfive women who inspire me: writers, painters, teachers, singers, engineers, social workers, professors, directors, journalists, and activists. 35 revolutionary women have confirmed participation:

So far, I have photographed and interviewed ten revolutionary women from the Bay Area. I have recorded their interviews and short stories of resilience. The footage will be presented on opening night of the exhibit. The photography book with their stories of resilience will be published and given as a GIFT to each young girl who attends the event. I will also upload some interviews here.

Thank you in advance for your generosity!

story:
365 Surfboards is a book commissioned by MVP Publishing in Minnesota. They had success with another book of mine called The Surfboard: Art, Style, Stoke. That book sold well and still sells more than six years later - and any book that makes money these days is a good book.

I was an editor at Surfer Magazine for 10 years before leaving to become a freelance writer. Since 1999 I have had 15 books published, but I tell people that because of Internet access to information, being a book writer these days is like being a great Viking rower just when they switched to sail power: Information is online for free, so books don't sell like they used to. And that makes photo budgets thin.

The Surfboard: Art, Style, Stoke sold well in hardcover then softcover, and the publisher hopes to have similar success with 365 Surfboards, which will be one in a series that began with 365 Guitars. I am hoping to persuade them to do 365 Skateboards next.

And after that, maybe 365 Snowboards.

The mission of 365 Surfboards is to collect that many existing, quality portraits of surfboards past, present and future from surfers, shapers and collectors. Collect them all, let Ben sort them out and then present the boards chronologically, describing each board in detail but also explaining where that board lies in the arc from the Caballito de tortora of 3000 BC Peru, to the olo and alaia of old Owyhee of the 19th Century and then into the 20th and 21st Centuries: hardwoods to balsa to plastics to the space age carbon fiber and composites of the 21st Century.

Some of the photographs are being provided by surfers, shapers and collectors but a fotografista named Lucia Griggi is working hard to take portraits of surfers and their boards. In the last two weeks of January Lucia did a working road trip from Seattle to La Jolla and took portraits of Matt Warshaw, Gerry Lopez, Greg Noll, Dale Webster, Jeff Clark, Wingnut, Chris Malloy, Bruce Brown, Griff Snyder, Skylar Peak, Allen Sarlo, Randy Hild, Eric "Bird" Huffman and Fernando Aguerre - all the way down in La Jolla.

Lucia's portraits are great and she will be taking more from La Jolla to Santa Barbara as the book is produced through March and April.

This Indiegogo is designed to pump up the photo budget for the book. 

Here on the cusp of the Internet revolution, publishing is such these days that photo budgets are often a fraction of what they need to be if everyone was being paid properly. The funds raised will pay Lucia for her portraits and also will be used to pay Guy Motil, Jorge Salas and other photographers and collectors for existing photos of surfboards, with action photos and other visuals.

Three hundred and sixty five surfboards is a lot of surfboards and while that many will allow this book to be detailed and comprehensive, a better photo budget will help to improve the quality and variety of those images.

There is a wide variety of perks available to those who pitch in: Take your pick from the author's extensive collection of historic surfing DVD - inventory available on request.

A copy of the book signed by the author and Lucia and maybe some of the surfers featured in the book - if we can track them down.

Quality prints of images from the book, if that interests you.

For anyone who really throws down, we'll consider sending Lucia to your house for a personal portrait session - if your house is within range and reason of southern Orange County.

Perks include a public thank you in the book, and just the satisfaction of helping an ambitious project overcome the challenge of a short deadline, a limited photo budget and organizing hundreds of boards into a book that does justice to everyone.

There is a Facebook for the project at https://www.facebook.com/365Boards

Thank you.
story_txt:
365 Surfboards is a book commissioned by MVP Publishing in Minnesota. They had success with another book of mine called The Surfboard: Art, Style, Stoke. That book sold well and still sells more than six years later - and any book that makes money these days is a good book.
I was an editor at Surfer Magazine for 10 years before leaving to become a freelance writer. Since 1999 I have had 15 books published, but I tell people that because of Internet access to information, being a book writer these days is like being a great Viking rower just when they switched to sail power: Information is online for free, so books don't sell like they used to. And that makes photo budgets thin.
The Surfboard: Art, Style, Stoke sold well in hardcover then softcover, and the publisher hopes to have similar success with 365 Surfboards, which will be one in a series that began with 365 Guitars. I am hoping to persuade them to do 365 Skateboards next.
And after that, maybe 365 Snowboards.
The mission of 365 Surfboards is to collect that many existing, quality portraits of surfboards past, present and future from surfers, shapers and collectors. Collect them all, let Ben sort them out and then present the boards chronologically, describing each board in detail but also explaining where that board lies in the arc from the Caballito de tortora of 3000 BC Peru, to the olo and alaia of old Owyhee of the 19th Century and then into the 20th and 21st Centuries: hardwoods to balsa to plastics to the space age carbon fiber and composites of the 21st Century.

story:
Short Summary

Hello. I’m Ceceilia Haasis-Nordeman and I love photography. I have been lucky enough to travel around the world and take photographs, and now I’d like to share them with you. 

I’m running this Indiegogo campaign to help fund a large coffee table book of my photographs. I’ve entitled this book The World From My View. It is a collection of my best prints. I love them and I hope you will enjoy them too. 

What We Need & What You Get

I need funding to pay for the limited edition manufacturing of the large format coffee table book. In return I am offering a wide selection of rewards. They include: postcards, posters, smaller versions of the book as well as signed limited edition versions of the coffee table book. The higher the level of your support, the more items you’ll receive.  

Risks & Challenges

There is little risk involved in contributing to this campaign. In the event that I do not make the $7500 goal, I will still send out all the other rewards, save for the limited edition book. For those who have supported at a higher level, instead of getting the coffee table book, you will receive 2 signed editions of the smaller book.  

Other Ways You Can Help

I offer postcards for the smallest contribution. However, if you cannot afford to contribute financially, you can still help by sharing this campaign with all your friends on Facebook or other social networks. Thanks for all your help!
