story:
For the last 6 years I have been working on a book "Arakan State of Mind"  which is focused on the Rohingya and Rakhine (Arakan) State, Myanmar.   One aspect of the story I'm trying to tell  concerns the lives of stateless Rohingyas who have been forced to flee into neighboring Bangladesh over the decades due to attacks by the Myanmar Military.  I was drawn to work on this project after Rohingya villages that I visited in Myanmar in 2011 were burned to the ground and many Rohingyas were killed.  Since 2011,  I have returned to Rakhine State twice and worked with Rohingyas living in Bangladesh, Thailand, Malaysia and the United States.  Most recently, I spent a week in southeastern Bangladesh near the Myanmar border documenting the genocide of the Rohingya people that is being carried out by their own military.  Unfortunately, over the last 2 months the Myanmar Military has once again been burning down hundreds of Rohingya villages in Rakhine State and killing Rohinyga civilians.  More than 600,000 have been forced out of Myanmar since August 25.  There are now nearly twice as many Rohingyas living in Bangladesh as there are living in Myanmar.  I will be going to Bangladesh near the Myanmar border at the beginning of December to continue my work with the Rohingya community with the goal to continue to raise awareness of the unbelievable conditions they are living in and the impact 4 decades of extreme oppression has had on their lives.  The current situation is dire and  Rohingya refugees are continuing to flee into Bangladesh.  Recent developments have haltered their movement.  Myanmar's military is holding thousands of refugees at the border fence and thousands more are stuck in no man's land in between Myanmar's border fence and the Naf River which separates the two countries.

I am hoping to raise $5,000 to help me to cover my plane tickets, ground transportation, hotels, fixers, and  translations  over the next two weeks of my trip. 

Recent work from Bangladesh:

http://www.chrisbealephoto.com/projects1/uncate...

Past work in Myanmar and Bangladesh:

http://www.chrisbealephoto.com/projects1/uncate...

http://roadsandkingdoms.com/2015/rohingya-2/

I sincerely thank you for your help in making this trip possible.  

Chris Beale

story:
Short Summary

Our Campaign

Two years ago, with funds raised through Indiegogo, photographers Robin Dahlberg, Sanne Vils Axelsen and Josee Schryer, and Rosebud Sioux tribal member Paula Antoine,  launched a summer photography intensive for youth on the Rosebud Sioux Reservation, at the Reservation's Boys & Girls Club in Mission, South Dakota.   In 2017, 18 youth between the ages of 8 and 13 participated, producing visually compelling stories about themselves and their communities which were displayed widely throughout the Reservation. 

    

In 2018,  26 youth participated, using cameras to explore and interpret traditional Lakota celestial mythology.   With assistance from Robin and Josee, the youth created 13 photomurals and a short video entitled Stars & Turnips, both of which were exhibited at San Francisco's California Academy of Sciences in May 2019, as part of Media Art Xploration's 2019: A Space Festival.   (The video attached to this Campaign is part of Stars & Turnips.)

                                             

 In what the Club's executive director, Glen Marshall, called "the experience of a lifetime,"  six kids and three adults traveled from South Dakota to San Francisco to see the show.

This summer, Robin and Josee are returning to the Boys & Girls Club to continue and expand the photography program.  We will again teach a two-week photography and videography intensive to teens at the Boys & Girls Club in Mission, and, for the first time, will offer a one-week introductory program to younger children at a second location - the Boys & Girls Club's clubhouse in Rosebud, South Dakota. 

In addition, we will travel to Rapid City, South Dakota, where the 13 photomurals and video first presented in San Francisco will be on display during Native POP:  People of the Plains; A Gathering of Arts and Culture.

Your donation will help us defray equipment costs, programmatic expenses and transportation and lodging costs.   We gladly volunteer our time.   

With your support, we will be able to continue to provide Rosebud youth with  opportunities to grow and develop as artists and valued community members. 

About the Reservation and the Boys & Girls Club

The Rosebud Sioux Reservation is the home of the Sicangu Oyate (the Upper Brulé Sioux Nation), a branch of the Lakota people also known as the Rosebud Sioux Tribe.   The Tribe has a proud history and a rich culture that emphasizes strong family and community ties, consensus decision-making and respect for nature and the earth.  

Yet, many Reservation families struggle with poverty, substance abuse and obesity-related health issues.  Because of the lack of economic opportunity, more than 45% of Reservation residents live below the federal poverty line.  These challenges weigh heavily on Reservation youth.  The Reservation's teen suicide rate is more than five times the national average.  

The Boys and Girls Club seeks to provide Reservation youth with the skills, resilience and self-confidence needed to confront these challenges and to become healthy young adults. 

Who are we?

Robin and Josee met about six years ago while working on their MFA's in Photography at the University of Hartford.  Robin now lives in New York City and Josee in Montreal.  Before becoming a photographer, Robin was a civil rights lawyer and worked with the Tribe over a period of ten years to ensure that tribal youth attending schools off the Reservation received appropriate educational services. She has taught photography extensively to both adults and children. Josee is interested in folklore, traditions and people’s attachment to places. She has spent the past 3 years working on reserved land exploring the territory and the culture of Northern Quebec’s inhabitants.  

Our Budget

Camera and computer equipment:                                            $4000

 --- 6 cameras 

--- 25 SD cards

--- 2 external hard drives

--- 25 Flash drives

--- Photographic paper

--- 1 HDMI cable

--- Batteries

--- Printer Ink 

Transportation and lodging:                                                            $2000

--- Rental cars to use on site  

--- Airfare to and from South Dakota

--- Extra baggage fees for equipment

--- Lodging for 2 weeks

 

Please donate to our campaign.

story:
Connected

Connected: The Abbreviated Adventures of a Self-Described Idealist is a photo book featuring a select collection of images from travels across five continents. This book originally started out as a promotional piece to showcase a sample of images to a small group of clients, but thanks to broader interest it's now being made into a fuller travel book.

The 8.5 x 11" soft-cover book will be 80 pages long, with at least 60 of those pages comprising images from around the globe. With your contributions, the book will grow larger, expanding by 20 pages for every $1500, and feature more destinations. 

Why "Connected"?

At the surface level, we are very different from each other. Often defined by our culture, ethnicity, religion, geography and lifestyle - these are many of the elements that inspire travelers to dust off their passports and visit lands and peoples afar. What we often find when we arrive is that despite our differences, we hold many of the same desires and ideals. We are, in a very real sense, connected in our shared humanity. Connected: The Abbreviated Adventures of a Self-Described Idealist, photographically explores the relationship between people, culture and geography while illuminating the humanity that connects us all.

The Photographer

The book will feature images (and short anecdotes) from travel photographer Matt Dutile. Matt has had the pleasure to travel across six different continents, with work published in a variety of international magazines including Islands, DestinAsian, Endless Vacation, National Geographic Traveler, Lonely Planet, Delta Sky and more. Connected will be curated from some of his personal favorite destinations and images.

Making Connected Larger

No matter the contributions received, this book will be made. You have the opportunity to help make it bigger and better by contributing to reach funding goals. The more books purchased, the more images and perks that can be included with each copy. You also have the opportunity to purchase large prints from the book or any of Matt Dutile's images found on his website. 

Here are what your contribution goals will help do:
  • At $1500 raised the book will expand from 80 to 100 pages. 
  • At $3000 raised it will expand another 20 pages.

Risks & Challenges

Since these will already be made for promotional purposes, there's no risks here in the book not getting made. You'll get your copy guaranteed. 

Please note the printing and shipping timeline may be a bit delayed depending on the availability of the printing house, and if there is a large quantity to fullfill. Thanks for your support and patience!

story:
MY NAME

My name is Beatrice and I am a photographer. In 2007 I won a scholarship to take a Masters in Photography and Visual Design at the Forma-NABA International Center, Milan. I’m specialized in photojournalism and research. In  December 2011 I won the prize Il Portfolio Italia with her work “Love Camping – Apologia dello stanziale” with Paola Fiorini. In February 2012 I exhibit in Milan, Orvieto, Rome and Padua, in the collective exhibition “Volontariamente.”(Voluntarily). In 2012 I was is a finalist for the Ponchielli Prize. In 2010, 2011, 2012 and 2014 I exhibited for the photography event “Prima Visione” (First Vision) at the Belvedere di Milano gallery.


I realised my project “Princess of Waterland” during a pilot mission carried out in 2014 by a group of doctors from the Hospital of Padua in cooperation with a little non-profit organization called Filo di Juta. The plan for the exhibition was born out of the wish to make known through a series of images the reality of life in Bangladesh with particular attention to the plight of women in the most marginalised groups of the population. My dream is having the possibility to explain through my picture the stories of my “princess”. 


The Association “Filo di Juta” has been active in the country for the past 15 years. It is based in the south, in the region of Chalna. In the years the organization has been working there, three schools have been built and made operative, teachers have been trained who have been selected from the heart of the local community and, thanks to the collection of funds, they are in the process of setting up a health centre to bring together the benefits of education and medical support.


MY DREAM

I believe that it is useful to be aware of the problems in existence at an international level by supplying the tools for reflection and investigation. Who are these women? What can I do to help them? Placed alongside some images are “narrative fragments” (created by Marco Vichi) which, through a positive and negative statement relating to the same picture, invite the observers not to stop at the first impression but instead to go beyond the images. I would like to have the opportunity to create prints,frames and leaflet of these photos to share the exhibition “Princess of Waterland” in Italy and all over the world. You can help me to makes it a reality!


HELP ME!

I do know how many people can help me with money, but I hope that lots of you can talk about these little princess.  You can share my project from my website www.beatricemancini.it

Thank you for all and keep in touch!

story:
Hi! 

My name is Patrick and I am an amateur photographer. I've been living in Köln for 10 years now and love this city with my very heart. Originally from the South of Germany, I was warmly welcomed here. People usually hail the tolerant and open-minded nature of this city... in my case, all of that was true and it became an inspiration fore me! 

Over five years ago, I made photography my hobby: I bought a trusty Nikon D60 and never looked back. Last year, I've upgraded to a D7000 since the old D60 had shown some wear. Looking back at all the photos I took from lovely city, I had an epiphany. I have to make a coffee table book, a photo book about Köln! Combining the things I love. This photo book will take you back, on the tourist side of the city, the traditions and take a peek into street phography and street art!  

I am not sure where this journey is going to lead me but I hope this project will become something beautiful! 

Thank you for your support! 


What do you get and what do I get? 

  • I plan to use the money to print 20 (+1 Tester) photo books @ blurb.com (since it has Lightroom & InDesign integration) and use the rest of the money to buy perks and pay for the postage. 
  • If the full amount is crowdfunded, 11 out of 20 photo books will be sent to the 100 & 50 Euro package supporters, the rest will be available to buy at cost price. If it is successful, I will try to make an ebook which all supporters will receive. 
  • Other perks are posters, chocolates and other great stuff! :) 
  • If I don't reach the minimal funding required for 20 books, I will try to print less books and keep in contact with supporters to pool ideas! 


follow-up, risks and consequences

  • This is my first Indiegogo-project so it might not be perfect, if you have any questions, contact me @ kirsch@patrick-kirsch.eu ! 
  • I already prepared a first draft of the photo book! Mostly the text is missing but the selection of photos is 99,9% done.
  • There are no real risks since you will get a perk for every contribution you make. I will not earn money at this point, I might earn some by selling the rest of the photo books (which is not guaranteed) 
  • To make the costs transparent: 550 Euros are for printing copies of the photo book and 150 Euros are needed to pay the perks, package and Inidegogo fees with a slight overhead of around 30 Euros! 
  • It's an adventure and an experiment - which YOU can support! 


You can also help by spreading my camapign on social networks or in your circle of friends! 

Thank you very much for reading until here and thank you for supporting in any way! Check http://www.patrick-kirsch.eu for my photography page! 
Patrick
story_txt:
Hi! 
My name is Patrick and I am an amateur photographer. I've been living in Köln for 10 years now and love this city with my very heart. Originally from the South of Germany, I was warmly welcomed here. People usually hail the tolerant and open-minded nature of this city... in my case, all of that was true and it became an inspiration fore me! Over five years ago, I made photography my hobby: I bought a trusty Nikon D60 and never looked back. Last year, I've upgraded to a D7000 since the old D60 had shown some wear. Looking back at all the photos I took from lovely city, I had an epiphany. I have to make a coffee table book, a photo book about Köln! Combining the things I love. This photo book will take you back, on the tourist side of the city, the traditions and take a peek into street phography and street art!  
I am not sure where this journey is going to lead me but I hope this project will become something beautiful! 
Thank you for your support! 


What do you get and what do I get? 


I plan to use the money to print 20 (+1 Tester) photo books @ blurb.com (since it has Lightroom & InDesign integration) and use the rest of the money to buy perks and pay for the postage. 
If the full amount is crowdfunded, 11 out of 20 photo books will be sent to the 100 & 50 Euro package supporters, the rest will be available to buy at cost price. If it is successful, I will try to make an ebook which all supporters will receive.  Other perks are posters, chocolates and other great stuff! :)  If I don't reach the minimal funding required for 20 books, I will try to print less books and keep in contact with supporters to pool ideas! 
    follow-up, risks and consequences 
This is my first Indiegogo-project so it might not be perfect, if you have any questions, contact me @ kirsch@patrick-kirsch.eu !  I already prepared a first draft of the photo book! Mostly the text is missing but the selection of photos is 99,9% done.
There are no real risks since you will get a perk for every contribution you make. I will not earn money at this point, I might earn some by selling the rest of the photo books (which is not guaranteed) 
To make the costs transparent: 550 Euros are for printing copies of the photo book and 150 Euros are needed to pay the perks, package and Inidegogo fees with a slight overhead of around 30 Euros! 
It's an adventure and an experiment - which YOU can support!     
You can also help by spreading my camapign on social networks or in your circle of friends! Thank you very much for reading until here and thank you for supporting in any way! Check http://www.patrick-kirsch.eu for my photography page! Patrick

story:
12/6/11 


Calendars printed...!!!!! 

I expect to see them in 5-7 business days, and anticipate shipping them all out before the 17th for holiday arrival. I am currently seeking a reliable online publishing source for continued sales... Will definitely post a link as soon as I have found one!! 
THANK YOU ALL FOR YOUR SUPPORT. This was a really stressful, but FUN project. I learned a lot, and can't wait to apply it all to NEXT YEAR'S installment. Bigger. Better. More!

xoxo



11/7/11


WOW! THANK YOU ALL for helping me hit my goal!!! My life has become saturated with donuts and dress-up AND I LOVE IT. We are nearing the end of photo shooting and, man-- is it a challenge to be director/ set designer/ hair and makeup/ model/ editorial eye/ publisher! Especially as an admittedly neurotic hyper-critical perfectionist.
For a bit of a timeline: I am shooting for a to-press date the last week of November, with the goal of shipping all calendars by the second week of December for holiday arrival. 

I am so grateful for everyone who helped make this project possible. After the project has gone to press, I will continue taking orders via the publisher's website, so you'll be able to order whenever is convenient for you until the end of 2012! I will post a link accordingly. 
I had a few minor technical issues with my page, resulting in my "claimed perks" disappearing. NO WORRIES to those who have already pre-ordered a calendar-- I still have all your information and will be fulfilling the orders as promised :o) 

10/24/11 Update

Overwhelmed by everyones support!! This project is now *well* underway and I am having such a blast working on it! I never realized how much WORK it is putting together photo shoots, ::phew:: ! 

Remember, every donation is effectively a pre-order. I really appreciate those of you going above &beyond. It's because of you (literally) that this project is even able to continue moving forward! $1100 seems like a lot of money until you do the math on 12 photo shoots!!

Please don't forget, 10% of proceeds and donations go to the Global Hunger Project -- a great charity aimed at ending global hunger. 

THANK YOU! 

Our Story

My name is Kat, and I love donuts. I run a donut blog at mewantdonut.tumblr.com


About a month ago, I began working on what I thought to be a fun little photo project with the goal of creating a themed pinup calendar. I love playing dress up and I love donuts, so I thought what the hay-- let's merge the ideas and make something more of this! 


Unfortunately, life has gotten in the way, as it so often does. Financial hardships have made continuing this project (with the intention of finishing before mid-December) a real challenge. So I am turning to the internet. The place where I keep all my invisible friends!


I humbly implore, oh friends across the globe, help me finish my project! It's sweet and sexy and colorful, will make a great addition to the office or gift for a friend! The photo shown above is an unedited sample of the sort of photos you can expect to find! Please help me make it better!!

The Impact

Helping fund this calendar project is the only way it will be done for 2012. Although I'd love to finish it regardless, there is just no way I can afford the production costs. Since I am aware that my problems are pretty small-potatoes in the larger scheme of thing, I will also be donating 10% of the money I raise to the Global Hunger Project-- a charity aimed at ending global hunger http://www.thp.org/

What We Need & What You Get

What do I need? Well, part of the funding for this project will go to expenses such as props, wardrobe, other people's time and equipment, and most importantly DONUTS. The remaining funds will go to production costs, including the printing of the calendar, which is the most expensive part.


What do you get?? Anyone who donates more than $18 will receive a calendar, once they're finished! Also, the largest donor before 11/18/11 gets the option of orchestrating one of our shoots-- you pick the featured donut and theme, and I will smile and make it happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

Help get the word out! If I finish this project, and it turns out well, I would love to expand it next year into a bigger, far more awesome project. But I can't do it without help!

story:
Umani a Milano, in breve

Nel tentativo di innamorarmi di nuovo della mia città ho deciso di girarla per trovare facce e storie. E’ l’unico modo che conosco. E voglio condividerlo.

Chi sono

Sono Stefano D’Andrea: scrivo per Radio 24 (Voi siete qui, di Matteo Caccia) e faccio fotografie. 

Faccio anche un sacco di altre cose: http://www.linkedin.com/in/stefanodandrea

Come si fa Umani a Milano

Io esco con una macchina fotografica e cammino per i marciapiedi dove fermo le persone che mi sembrano più interessanti, per chiedere se posso fotografarle. Nello stesso tempo domando qualcosa sul loro momento di vita, sulla loro giornata, sul loro borsello o sulla loro bambina. 

Il risultato è un ritratto, con una storia. Milano ne è piena, io provo a raccoglierle e raccontarle.

Di cosa ha bisogno

Oltre alla mia passione e spinta a incontrare le persone, il progetto ha bisogno di tempo, lavoro e attrezzature. Tutto ciò vuol dire anche denaro.

Perché contribuire

Perché il progetto possa andare avanti, almeno fino all'Expo!

story:
What Is It

This June 2019, SOHO PHOTO GALLERY will celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall Riots with a beautiful exhibition featuring 23 photographers. The exhibition is curated by Soho Photo Gallery photographers Bill Travis and Larry Davis.

We are making a book so that this exhibition can live on forever! That's why we're on Indiegogo.

What We Are Doing and What We Need

Our book is 10 X 8 inches with 128 pages, 64 beautiful full-page illustrations, artist statements, and texts by experts on the legacy of Stonewall and its influence on creative photography. It costs a lot of money to put this together. But with your donation we can make it happen! 

Please consider donating.
Thank you!

Featured Photographers

Ronaldo Aguiar - Berena Alvarez - James Bidgood - Vincent Cianni - Joyce Culver - John Paul Evans - Sunil Gupta - David Hilliard - Robert Kalman - Rivka Katvan - David Lebe - Patrick McNabb - Slava Mogutin - Barbara Nitke - Lissa Rivera - Jeff Sheng - Pacifico Silano - Sage Sohier - Sam Stoich - Bill Travis - Arthur Tress - Annie Tritt - Sophia Wallace

 

Who We Are

Soho Photo Gallery is a not-for-profit foundation that has been promoting photography as art since 1971, helping photographers of all creeds, backgrounds, and nationalities to show their work. We believe photography is important not only for documenting our times but also for educating those who seek to learn about history through images. For more information about us please check our website: www.sohophoto.com

story:
We don't want to give too much away.....so an impression of how it will look.

Get a Grip......
Our portrait grip is a simple idea, but it seems to have caused some confusion with some people. To set the record straight, this grip is not a traditional style battery grip, which would normally need to be designed for individual models of camera. This is a PORTRAIT  grip, and as such, it is designed to give more control of the camera when using it at awkward angles. The grip is simply attached to the camera in the same manner as a tripod.
We have decided that if the campaign target isn't reached, the project will continue for as long as possible, and everyone who has backed us will get a full refund as soon as we possibly can. In short, if you purchase a perk and we cant follow through, we will refund your donation. 

What We Need & What You Get

The grip is in final design stages, we aim to produce a series of working models within the next month, and very quickly afterwards the finished product available to everyone who invests.


For your help, we will put everyone who funds £5 or more on our mailing list, not only for updates to the project but also to be the first to receive the finished grip! So the benefits are...... 

  1. Be kept up to date on the final product and its availability to order
  2. Receive a finished grip to try out for yourself. 
  3. The chance to have your say on any design flaws or alterations needed to the finished product (although we firmly believe there shouldn't be any, if at all) 


    Risks & Challenges

    We strongly feel that this project is very close to achieving its main aim, which is to produce a grip for photographers that they can use on any camera. 

    However as with any project, we cant tell the future and cant promise that everything will go as planned. What we do believe is that if we can get close to our target goal for funding, we will at least get the first batch out to everyone who is part of this journey. Afterwards we may need to take a step back and re-evaluate the situation, but this would be a worst case scenario and our determination to see this project become a success is too great for failure.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    We know times are tough, and we realise that not everyone can spare some cash just now. what we do hope is that you are intrigued enough by this project to mention it to other photographers, help us get the message out and reach more people than we can at the moment. The louder this project is, and the more people that become interested, then the less chance this project has of failing.

story:
What is My First Camera Project about?

The project aims to provide free cameras, photography and story-telling training to children living in Kibera Slum, offering  an artistic and educational opportunity to young people who have been living on the outskirts of the society, forgotten by the world and by their own government. For these children, these cameras will be the first cameras they have ever owned. 

Through a participatory methodology, we will teach children to operate the camera as a tool, to interpret images and to understand the power of photographs to take the message, to engage and mobilize people and to advance social change. 

The final output of the project - a collection of photographs taken by the children, will be gather in a photobook and gallery exhibitions, which will be used to draw attention to how the rights of these children might be improved. 

 

 

 

 

 

I believe photography can open a door to dreams. Creating art will expand children's ability to interact with the world around them and will provide a new set of skills for self-expression and communication, building self-confidence and creativity. While the project will provide a unique insight into their world, for the children this will be a life-changing experience and a valuable opportunity to express themselves through the camera lens.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

How can people survive in a place like this? Despite its problems and lack of resources, Kibera is also a gigantic and incredible marketplace and an inspiring example of resilience. Business is being done all around and you can find here whatever you want! In Kibera, people dream about changing their community. People think outside of the box to find solutions for their needs.  Women work together to make clothes, jewellery and food which they sell in shops in the slum. Activists stand for people's right to live decent lives.

 

 

 

 

The Impact

 

 

"Photography will help me in my future".

Through a participatory photography methodology, this project aims to give a voice to the children of Kibera and their underrepresented experiences. This is an opportunity for them to get actively involved in the community and to be seen and heard in their society and worldwide. By making photographs of their everyday life, children will develop a life-long skill and learn how to use photography as a mean of communication, advocacy and awareness raising. Photography is a universal language and it can act as a catalyst for greater international involvement and positive change. 

As speakers and writers, participants will use oral and written language to present their opinions and their views. As listeners, they will analyze experiences and ideas presented by others. By discussing their work, children will develop their sense of who they are in the world and will learn to appreciate various perspectives. 

With art, children can reflect and imagine. Photography will inspire curiosity and creativity, then children  can search for opportunities out of their neighborhood or can use their photography and story-telling skills to raise funds for the school or to promote new businesses. In capturing their life within the camera frame, they will be building, image by image, their self-confidence and a greater sense of control over their lives. The project will help children to understand that the life of young people in Kibera is a story worth telling and that there is a place for them, in their community, in their country, in the world.

 

 

 

 

 

What We Need

I spent some months designing the project and connecting with local partners. Now it is time to implement the project. To make it a reality, we need:

 

  • Cameras and equipment (printer, paper, memory cards)
  • Website for online gallery
  • Postproduction, edition and printing of the work
  • Public exhibition of the final work
  • Museums and galleries visits - admission and transportation
  • Project coordination, monitoring and evaluation
  • Post cards and prints for the reward
  • Shipping expense

 

 

 

 

With your support

 

 

  • We will provide children with digital cameras and the skills to document their lives, their community, their families, their friends and their daily activities. This is their chance to say what they see!
  • Each week children will be asked to take photos with specific themes as part of the larger project. In the weekly tutoring sessions they will have the opportunity to discuss the pictures and to develop personal narratives, writing the story their photos tell. 
  • We will invite local artists to visit tutoring sessions and to share their work, providing a positive role model and inspiration.
  • Museum and galleries visits will be organized, giving children the opportunity to see original artwork, to reflect and to discover their potential.
  • Each children will build a body of photographic work and narratives - their own portfolio, which is the best way to evaluate the result of their participation.
  • Each week we will post on our official Facebook page the "image of the week", then you will be able to stay informed about the project and children can evaluate their progress.
  • The images created will be gathered in a photobook which will be launched with purpose of raising funds to feed back to the community.
  • We will present children's work at public exhibition in Kenya, inviting local policy-makers, youth organizations and major media. The culminating display of images will allow children to have their accomplishments recognised in a public forum, as well to see themselves as artists.

 

 

What you get

 

If you have ever dreamed of making a real difference in other people's lives, this is your opportunity! You will be able to stay informed about project developments and to see the end result.

Together we ensure that these real life stories are seen far and wide.

 Join us and become part of the adventure! 

 

 

 

 

     

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't donate, that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Help us SPREAD THE WORD and making this project a HUGE SUCCESS! Tell about the campaign your friends, your family and everyone you know in real life and social networks!

    • Share the video, promote it, talk about it!!

    • Like, follow, and share the official Facebook page, to stay informed about project developments!

    • Feel free to help promoting My First Camera Project using all the share tools found on Indiegogo!

    • Know a journalist or news outlet?  We need local and international media to write about our project and to help us make it a reality!

     

    Official Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/myfirstcamera

     

     

     

     

    Special Thanks to Fred Costa for editing our video! Reach him at http://www.fredcosta.me/

     

    "Passionate photographers  must never cease believing that their images do matter".

By making photographs of their everyday life, children will develop a life-long skill and learn how to use photography as a mean of communication, advocacy and awareness raising. Photography is a universal language and it can act as a catalyst for greater international involvement and positive change. As speakers and writers, participants will use oral and written language to present their opinions and their views. As listeners, they will analyze experiences and ideas presented by others. By discussing their work, children will develop their sense of who they are in the world and will learn to appreciate various perspectives. With art, children can reflect and imagine. Photography will inspire curiosity and creativity, then children  can search for opportunities out of their neighborhood or can use their photography and story-telling skills to raise funds for the school or to promote new businesses. In capturing their life within the camera frame, they will be building, image by image, their self-confidence and a greater sense of control over their lives. The project will help children to understand that the life of young people in Kibera is a story worth telling and that there is a place for them, in their community, in their country, in the world.     What We NeedI spent some months designing the project and connecting with local partners. Now it is time to implement the project. To make it a reality, we need: 
Cameras and equipment (printer, paper, memory cards)
Website for online gallery
Postproduction, edition and printing of the work
Public exhibition of the final work
Museums and galleries visits - admission and transportation
Project coordination, monitoring and evaluation
Post cards and prints for the reward
Shipping expense
    With your support  
We will provide children with digital cameras and the skills to document their lives, their community, their families, their friends and their daily activities. This is their chance to say what they see!
Each week children will be asked to take photos with specific themes as part of the larger project. In the weekly tutoring sessions they will have the opportunity to discuss the pictures and to develop personal narratives, writing the story their photos tell. 
We will invite local artists to visit tutoring sessions and to share their work, providing a positive role model and inspiration.
Museum and galleries visits will be organized, giving children the opportunity to see original artwork, to reflect and to discover their potential.
Each children will build a body of photographic work and narratives - their own portfolio, which is the best way to evaluate the result of their participation.
Each week we will post on our official Facebook page the "image of the week", then you will be able to stay informed about the project and children can evaluate their progress.
The images created will be gathered in a photobook which will be launched with purpose of raising funds to feed back to the community.
We will present children's work at public exhibition in Kenya, inviting local policy-makers, youth organizations and major media. The culminating display of images will allow children to have their accomplishments recognised in a public forum, as well to see themselves as artists.
  What you get If you have ever dreamed of making a real difference in other people's lives, this is your opportunity! You will be able to stay informed about project developments and to see the end result.Together we ensure that these real life stories are seen far and wide. Join us and become part of the adventure!       Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't donate, that doesn't mean you can't help:
Help us SPREAD THE WORD and making this project a HUGE SUCCESS! Tell about the campaign your friends, your family and everyone you know in real life and social networks!
Share the video, promote it, talk about it!!
Like, follow, and share the official Facebook page, to stay informed about project developments!
Feel free to help promoting My First Camera Project using all the share tools found on Indiegogo!
Know a journalist or news outlet?  We need local and international media to write about our project and to help us make it a reality!
 Official Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/myfirstcamera    Special Thanks to Fred Costa for editing our video! Reach him at http://www.fredcosta.me/ "Passionate photographers  must never cease believing that their images do matter".

story:
Greetings

Greetings from the wild Ginkgo hamlet, located inside the West Tianmu Mountains, a member of the UNESCO's 'Man and Biosphere Reserve Network', Inside its abundant vegetation, live hundreds of wild millennium Ginkgos.

Surrounded by grand mountain ranges, Yangjia Village,the wild Ginkgo hamlet is situated in a long valley, with a population of over 1,200 people, hundreds of houses were built along several streams. There are a lot of Ginkgo trees scattered besides houses and in valleys. Each family has several female Ginkgo trees, whose seeds are one of our main sources of income.

As a native, I grew up, I played in the wild Ginkgo forests. I began to photograph Ginkgos late last century. I learned my craft through apprenticeship to a disciple of a master traditional Chinese painter Shoutian Pan. My works have been published and exhibited internationally. And I have been editing and polishing the book for recent years.

History

God created the earth. Dinosaurs and Ginkgos flourished. After the biological mass extinction 65 million years ago, plus the Quaternary glaciers which swept across the planet 2 million years ago, most forms of animals and plants disappeared. One species of Ginkgo tree survived in sheltered mountainous areas in east China. I am lucky enough to be a native.

In 1989, at Yi Ma Formation of Henan Province, China, a team of paleontologists led by Zhiyan Zhou (my advisor) and Bole Zhang unearthed some Ginkgo fossils, that they later traced back 170 million years--the oldest Ginkgo fossils found to date. Following is their leaf and seed patterns:

Because of their straight trunks and extraordinary shapes, Ginkgo trees were often planted in front of temples, lending an atmosphere of awe and solemnity. Old Buddhist monks liked to use walking sticks made of Ginkgo twigs, when they traveled as missionaries, they stuck their sticks into the soil inside the temple, where new trees would grow from these sticks. By this method Ginkgos spread to Korean peninsula and Japan about 1,500 years ago. About one thousand years later, Ginkgo nuts were carried from Japan to Holland, and the first Ginkgo tree in Europe grew. From Holland, Ginkgo was transplanted to other European countries and the U.S.A.

My Advisors

The book delves deep and wide, besides wild Ginkgo sceneries, it encompasses history, wonders, legends, folklores, etc, supervised by top scientists, including:

Zhiyan Zhou, academician, Research Professor of Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, one of the authoritative person in researching Ginkgo history.

Shiyan Xing, professor of College of Forestry, Shangdong Agriculture University, vice chair of Ginkgo Branch of China Forestry Association.

Zhaogen Zhang, historian, archeologist, former associate curator of Suzhou Museum, is currently the director of the Suzhou Institute of Archaeology, he has extensive knowledge on Chinese history.

Sheung Wai, (Sherry) Chan,  linguist in English and Chinese, a bilingual poet living in Australia.

Yusheng (Christopher) Liu,  former associate professor of Biology at Prairie View A&M University, U.S.A.

Get to know more about the story of wild Ginkgos?  Download 100+ pages of the Ginkgo picture book, by clicking the link:  

http://jmp.sh/6j2iXab

or you could get the whole ebook of 320 pages for 5 dollars by claiming any perk on the right. Discover and share wonders of Nature.

Perks

The book, hard cover, bilingual, in English and Chinese, 300 pages, 250+ color images, printed on 135 lb/200 gsm matt paper, 26 x 25 cm, /10.24 x 9.84 in. weight is about 4 lb. In order to keep the weight plus package under 2 kg, (which is the most convenient transportation packet in most countries), I may reduce some pages in the printing edition. 

All perks may add shipping charges, ranging from $2 and up. As the book is heavy, I will ship in lot by sea to my agents' warehouses in your country/continent, they will dispatch to you individually. 

Canvas style pigment prints

Here are the 4 canvas style pigment prints. Each image derived from a millennium-old Ginkgo, then computer enhanced.

A

B

C

D

Tours

There are too much to be expressed by any words or images, so the book only serves as a taster. It would be my pleasure to welcome you to see wild Ginkgos here in the Tianmu Mountains, east China, where I am living. I will show you around.

 

Q/A

--Why the goal is set at $1000?

--Frankly, this amount is far from printing quality books. Publishing a book in China is quite different from that in the West. My publisher has already started the process, it has to pass the authority’s approval. And since I am not a star in China to guarantee the sale, I have to pay all the costs involved. I have been lucky to secure some rich friends to support this project. The proceeds here are supplementary. Increasing the volume of printing would reduce the cost per copy. So this is a win/win situation. Most of all, I would like to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to a lot of people who have encouraged and supported me along the long long way.

 

--Will the book be available in major bookstores in other parts of the world?

--Not sure, with ever expanding network of Chinese operated warehouses scattered in a lot of countries, and my Linkedin contact number grows fast, now exceeding 17k, I can easily handle myself. Moreover, I would be happy to make friends around the world.

 

I have been grateful

In fact, a lot (hundreds) of people have offered their kind comments in shaping the present edition. I have been so grateful to them along the way. Here are a few.

-----------------------------------------------------

 ‘What beautiful photos! Great to see Ginkgo in so many different habitats. I would strongly encourage you to publish the book.’

--Dr Mark Nesbitt, Curator, Economic Botany Collection Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, United Kingdom

May 08. 2016

--------------------------------------

'This manuscript offers a wonderful glimpse of the stately ginkgo from its origins in China. The author and photographer show adoration for this most ancient of trees. I was gifted a digital copy to peruse and shall cherish it. The images are touching and the prose poetic. Love the history and folk lore as well as popular references. A wonderful tribute to tree we have only sparingly planted in Nova Scotian cities and towns.'

--Ms. Marian Munro, Curator of Botany, Nova Scotia Museum, Canada

May 09, 2016

-----------------------------------------------------

‘I also showed it to our librarian, and we both agree that the photography and design are stunning. It is a very lyrical combination of imagery, poetry and information about the treasured Ginkgos in China.’

--Ms. Lugene B. Bruno, Curator of Art & Senior Research Scholar, Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation, Carnegie Mellon University, U.S.A

May 14, 2016

----------------------------------------------------

‘This is a beautiful book about a beautiful and intriguing plant. The photographs and stories are inspiring, and add to our enjoyment of the fascinating Ginkgo. Jimmy Shen has created a work of art and science!’

--Tim Entwisle, Professor, Director and Chief Executive of Royal Botanic Gardens Victoria, Australia

June 19, 2016

-------------------------------------------------------

‘This is an amazing book that will find its way onto everyone's bookshelf who is interested in Ginkgos. It has fabulous images of Ginkgos in the wild and cultivation.’

--Dr. Tony Kirkham, Head of the arboretum at the Royal Botanic Gardens Kew, United Kingdom

June 29, 2016

-------------------------------------------------------

‘Your exploration of Ginkgo biloba and the relationship between Chinese people and this remarkable tree through outstanding photographs, careful documentation and poetry is very important. You beautifully illustrate the interconnections between beauty and utility in this enduring relationship. The nature of this relationship over thousands of years is important for our understanding of a sustainable future. This is an important quest for you to continue.’

--Stephen Forbes, Director, Botanic Gardens of South Australia, Adelaide, Australia, Chair of the Council of Heads of Australian Botanic Gardens Australian

Aug. 21, 2016

----------------------------------

I just LOVE your book about "everything Ginkgo!" You have creatively woven fact with story, technical language with poetry, and amazing legends with dry history. The visuals are extraordinary and truly inspiring to the senses.

Many thanks for sharing and I know this book will be a huge success once published.

--Margaret (Meg) Lowman, Ph.D. Director of Global Initiatives/Lindsay Chair of Botany Institute for Biodiversity Science and Sustainability California Academy of Sciences

Oct. 02, 2016

----------------------------------

‘It is an impressive compilation of information, anecdotes, medical remedies and even recipes from all over China. Some of the illustrations are quite spectacular! It must have taken considerable time and effort to gather all the information and photos from across the country. The book is a valuable resource for anyone wanting to know about Ginkgo and its long heritage. Great job!’

--Prof. Stephen McLoughlin, Swedish Museum of Natural History, Sweden

Oct. 12, 2016

---------------------------------------------

 ‘This is a beautiful and wonderfully complete body of work. I will take time to go through and read thoroughly, it truly deserves time to absorb and reflect. I would love to see this work being showcased in our garden and to be enjoyed by others who appreciate the nature and lore of Ginkgo.’

--Kevin Frediani, Inverewe Property Manager at the National Trust for Scotland, Honorary Lecturer Urban Agriculture, The University of Nottingham U.K.

Oct. 20, 2016

-------------------------------------------------------

‘Concerning your book, it is a delightful balance of art and information. I always love the Ginkgo for its beauty and place in natural history. I wish we were able to grow them in Florida but, alas it is not happy here. I did grow them in Michigan and enjoyed their ancient appeal. Your book really captured their mystique in a thought provoking and artistic manner. I will of course forward any interest your way as, alas as mentioned Florida does not see the tree grown this far south in the sub tropics.’

--Steven J. Royer, Professor, Palm Beach State College, U.S.A.

Oct. 25, 2016

----------------------------------

‘The Ginkgo book looks beautiful and extremely interesting. Thanks so much for being the champion for conserving the amazing Ginkgo tree!’

--Simon Stuart, Chair, Species Survival Commission, the International Union for Conservation of Nature

Nov. 09, 2016

----------------------------------

‘It was fascinating to learn more about the unique history of the Ginkgos, as well as how they fit culturally in both artistic and botanical traditions in China. This was clearly a labor of love for you, and you should be applauded for a fine work . . . and for sharing it with others!!’ Dec. 07, 2016

 'The book continues to amaze me . . . a beautiful work of art, science, and spirituality. Well  done!!'  July, 10, 2018

-- J. Eric Smith, President and CEO, TREE Fund, U.S.A.

----------------------------------

'Your work is absolutely beautiful! I am so grateful to you for sharing it with me.'

--Katie Frohardt, Executive Director, Wild Earth Allies

Dec. 07, 2016

----------------------------------

‘This is absolutely beautiful. The photographs are fantastic. You should be very proud of this book.’

--Rodney Honeycutt, Professor, Chairperson of Natural Science Division, Pepperdine University, U.S.A.

April 4, 2017

----------------------------------

‘I enjoyed reading the online version of your book on Ginkgos today. It is an amazing compilation of information, stories and folklore. The immense amount of work and attention to detail is obvious. There are places where the English translation could be improved. And perhaps somewhere you might want to address and dispute the widespread opinion among botanists that no verifiably wild Ginkgos exist.

Thank you so much for sharing your work with me. I hope that more people can become aware of your work.’

--Ross Clark, Professor Emeritus, Botany at Eastern Kentucky University, U.S.A.

Oct. 23, 2017

----------------------------------

‘The book is very beautiful, with a beautiful design, and the fact that you have edited it bilingually (in English and Chinese) gives it an air of superiority. ’

--Monica AXINI, Executive Manager, prof. at Monachus Group of Scientific Research and Ecological Education, Romania

Oct. 30, 2017

----------------------------------

‘What a delightful book. Not only the trees - but I am fascinated by the uses of wood and timber and the way the Gingko woods are managed.’

--Ian Rotherham, Editor of Arboricultural Journal, Professor at Sheffield Hallam University, U. K.

Nov. 08, 2017

----------------------------------

‘Gingko:The Living Fossil is lovely and important. Congratulations on such a special exploration of a tree and its culture. Your obsession is a good one. It is important, because it reminds us of something most people seem to have forgotten, that nature has shaped human culture since the beginning, even as human culture increasingly dominated nature. Your work provides a gateway for us to get back to where we need to be. Keep exploring, Jimmy!’

--Vance G. Martin, President, WILD Foundation, Chairman, Wilderness Specialist Group (IUCN/WCPA)

Nov. 20, 2017

----------------------------------

‘This is a very beautiful book. Thank you for sharing it with me. I particularly like the text along with the photographs, including the list of the 3,000-year-old trees and the couple trees. Congratulations on your achievement and thank you for sharing these trees' stories.’

--Sophia Shaw, Adjunct Professor of Social Impact at Kellogg School of Management, Former President & CEO of Chicago Botanic Garden

Nov. 26, 2017

----------------------------------

‘My first reaction was, what a wonderful production! I will look forward to reading it.’

--Chris Cleal, Head of Botany at Amgueddfa Cymru - National Museum Wales, U. K.

Dec. 06, 2017

----------------------------------

‘Like the redwoods of California, China's Ginkgo's are ancient forest survivors that have always inspired awe for their beauty and longevity. What Jimmy Shen has also captured, though, are the charm and rich cultural history of these golden, graceful trees in their native land.’

--Michael Brune, executive director of the Sierra Club,U.S.A., via Jim Bradbury, Communications Specialist, Sierra Club National

Dec. 20, 2017

----------------------------------

‘The book is very nice! I enjoyed it a lot, beautiful photos and interesting facts about this ancient and magnificent species. Liked the legends part, stories showing strong bondages between the tree and humans throughout the history.’

--Ana Strbenac, Head of the Expertise Division at Croatian Agency for the Environment and Nature (ex SINP)，Croatia

Feb. 05, 2018

----------------------------------

Your book was astonishing, I believe that the ancient traditions linked to a plant species are one of the most interesting parts of our history. Also for this reason I want to thank the authors for sharing the wonderful images, the history and the interesting cultural connotations of Ginkgo biloba.

--Alberto Giuntoli, PhD, Adjunct Professor at the University of Florence, Associated to the National Research Council of Italy, President of the Tuscan Society of Horticulture

Mar. 31, 2018  

----------------------------------

It is impossible to pigeonhole this book into any one category. A sensitive blend of the sciences, humanities, and arts, a most remarkable tree is brought to life through spectacular photos and engaging text. At a time of so much biodiversity loss, I wish every species could have a Jimmy Shen, someone to tell its story with admiring words and inspiring images. I have always been fascinated by the Ginkgo. I now have many more reasons to be.

--Quentin Wheeler, President, College of Environmental Science and Forestry, The Ohio State University, U.S.A.

Apr. 04, 2018

----------------------------------

‘My first reaction is that your pictures are very beautiful indeed. I have seen a lot of photographs of Ginkgo - and taken many myself - but your images are really very special - and some (for example the fallen leaves with frost) are very unusual. Beautiful!’

--Sir Peter Crane, FRS, President of the Oak Spring Garden Foundation, former Director of the Royal Botanic Gardens in Kew, London, former dean of the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies at Yale University.

May 15, 2018

----------------------------------

"I have long been fascinated by the ancient Gingko since I first learned about it in forestry school. As a symbol of eternal life, I carry a Gingko leaf with me wherever I go to keep me safe and grounded to the Earth. I was delighted to have the opportunity to view Jimmy Shen's magnificent photo collection of ancient, old and young Gingko trees in their stunning natural environment. Jimmy has poured so much love and beauty into this wonderful creation and for that I am deeply grateful."

--Scott Poynton, Founder, The Forest Trust

May 18, 2018 

----------------------------------

‘This is a wonderful book on a wonderful plant with wonderful pictures! Congratulations. I look forward to the printed version.’

--Koen Camelbeke, Executive Director at Arboretum Wespelaar, Belgium

June 13, 2018

----------------------------------

‘Thank you for sending me virtual copy of your magnificent book of imperial quality. I hope your efforts of getting it published as you wish will be successful.’

J.J. (Hans) Groenendijk, Senior Expert International Cooperation and Development, TISE Consultancy; Interim Chief Technical Advisor Natural Reserve of Ngiri Triangle Project (DRCongo), World Wildlife Fund, The Hague Area, Netherlands

June 19, 2018

----------------------------------

‘It is indeed great to hear that all of your hard work and taking the comments of others into consideration to make the Gingko book the best it can be. Congratulations on the soon to be published edition. I know it takes a lot of work to visualize a project like this and persevere over time to make it a reality.’

--James R. Shevock, Botany Research Associate, Fellow, California Academy of Sciences (CAS), the U.S.A.

June 19, 2018

----------------------------------

'You must be delighted with the progress you have made with the Ginkgo book – it’s looking really good – a very smart production on a fascinating subject.'

--Dr Mark Johnston MBE, FArborA (Hon), FCIHort, FICFor, Independent scholar: arboriculture, landscape and urban forestry, Based in Belfast, Northern Ireland

June 22, 2018

----------------------------------

'I am grateful to Jimmy Shen for sharing his passion with the world like this. Years of experience have done a beautiful job of showing these ancient trees, both close up and far away, as part of their natural environment. They are not the pristine specimens of carefully manicured botanic gardens, but their rugged natural state is no less impressive! This book will surely bring new appreciation of the species to many plant lovers.'

-- Matt Borden, Doctor of Plant Medicine , University of Florida, U.S.A.

July 16,2018

----------------------------------

By the way, I am honored to be featured at Global Diversity Foundation https://www.global-diversity.org/a-photographers-passion-for-a-living-fossil/

...

 

I am going to shoot a documentary

My advisor, Prof. Shiyan Xing led a team of 100 plus professionals a few years ago, conducted field investigations on Ginkgo resources in China for a period of 3 years, and totaling over 62,138 miles/100,000 km. Based on the updated information, I am going to shoot a documentary. This time I am learning cinematography.

And if you are interested to join the team, please contact me. Climb a high mountain to shoot an ancient Ginkgo; See these leaves shivering in the breeze...

 

Where are these butterflies transformed from Ginkgo leaves flying?

Find out in the book.

 

Tell You a Secret

We all know male and female ginkgos are separate trees. There are no bees involved as go-betweens. How do Male and Female Ginkgos Date? In spring, pollen cones grow on male trees while the ovule develops on the females. Carried by the wind, pollen travels miles across hills and rivers, meanwhile the ovule sends out a drop of liquid on the top to catch pollen passing by.

Get to know more about the story of wild Ginkgos? Download 100+ pages of the Ginkgo picture book, by clicking the link:  

http://jmp.sh/6j2iXab

or you could get the whole ebook of 320 pages for 5 dollars by claiming perks on the right. Discover and share wonders of Nature.

 

Please spread this campaign

I have no Facebook, Twitter, Youtube or Vimeo account, I am an internet dummy, besides no access to them here in China. Please spread this campaign with your friends in your social media or send to your email contacts who you think might be interested.

Well, I have a linked-in account and have 17k contacts.  https://www.linkedin.com/in/ginkgo/  You could also meet me there.

Discover and share wonders of Nature.

Great job!’--Prof. Stephen McLoughlin, Swedish Museum of Natural History, SwedenOct. 12, 2016--------------------------------------------- ‘This is a beautiful and wonderfully complete body of work. I will take time to go through and read thoroughly, it truly deserves time to absorb and reflect. I would love to see this work being showcased in our garden and to be enjoyed by others who appreciate the nature and lore of Ginkgo.’--Kevin Frediani, Inverewe Property Manager at the National Trust for Scotland, Honorary Lecturer Urban Agriculture, The University of Nottingham U.K.Oct. 20, 2016-------------------------------------------------------‘Concerning your book, it is a delightful balance of art and information. I always love the Ginkgo for its beauty and place in natural history. I wish we were able to grow them in Florida but, alas it is not happy here. I did grow them in Michigan and enjoyed their ancient appeal. Your book really captured their mystique in a thought provoking and artistic manner. I will of course forward any interest your way as, alas as mentioned Florida does not see the tree grown this far south in the sub tropics.’--Steven J. Royer, Professor, Palm Beach State College, U.S.A.Oct. 25, 2016----------------------------------‘The Ginkgo book looks beautiful and extremely interesting. Thanks so much for being the champion for conserving the amazing Ginkgo tree!’--Simon Stuart, Chair, Species Survival Commission, the International Union for Conservation of NatureNov. 09, 2016----------------------------------‘It was fascinating to learn more about the unique history of the Ginkgos, as well as how they fit culturally in both artistic and botanical traditions in China. This was clearly a labor of love for you, and you should be applauded for a fine work . . . and for sharing it with others!!’ Dec. 07, 2016 'The book continues to amaze me . . . a beautiful work of art, science, and spirituality. Well  done!!'  July, 10, 2018-- J. Eric Smith, President and CEO, TREE Fund, U.S.A.----------------------------------'Your work is absolutely beautiful! I am so grateful to you for sharing it with me.'--Katie Frohardt, Executive Director, Wild Earth AlliesDec. 07, 2016----------------------------------‘This is absolutely beautiful. The photographs are fantastic. You should be very proud of this book.’--Rodney Honeycutt, Professor, Chairperson of Natural Science Division, Pepperdine University, U.S.A.April 4, 2017----------------------------------‘I enjoyed reading the online version of your book on Ginkgos today. It is an amazing compilation of information, stories and folklore. The immense amount of work and attention to detail is obvious. There are places where the English translation could be improved. And perhaps somewhere you might want to address and dispute the widespread opinion among botanists that no verifiably wild Ginkgos exist.Thank you so much for sharing your work with me. I hope that more people can become aware of your work.’--Ross Clark, Professor Emeritus, Botany at Eastern Kentucky University, U.S.A.Oct. 23, 2017----------------------------------‘The book is very beautiful, with a beautiful design, and the fact that you have edited it bilingually (in English and Chinese) gives it an air of superiority. ’--Monica AXINI, Executive Manager, prof. at Monachus Group of Scientific Research and Ecological Education, RomaniaOct. 30, 2017----------------------------------‘What a delightful book. Not only the trees - but I am fascinated by the uses of wood and timber and the way the Gingko woods are managed.’--Ian Rotherham, Editor of Arboricultural Journal, Professor at Sheffield Hallam University, U. K.Nov. 08, 2017----------------------------------‘Gingko:The Living Fossil is lovely and important. Congratulations on such a special exploration of a tree and its culture. Your obsession is a good one. It is important, because it reminds us of something most people seem to have forgotten, that nature has shaped human culture since the beginning, even as human culture increasingly dominated nature. Your work provides a gateway for us to get back to where we need to be. Keep exploring, Jimmy!’--Vance G. Martin, President, WILD Foundation, Chairman, Wilderness Specialist Group (IUCN/WCPA)Nov. 20, 2017----------------------------------‘This is a very beautiful book. Thank you for sharing it with me. I particularly like the text along with the photographs, including the list of the 3,000-year-old trees and the couple trees. Congratulations on your achievement and thank you for sharing these trees' stories.’--Sophia Shaw, Adjunct Professor of Social Impact at Kellogg School of Management, Former President & CEO of Chicago Botanic GardenNov. 26, 2017----------------------------------‘My first reaction was, what a wonderful production! I will look forward to reading it.’--Chris Cleal, Head of Botany at Amgueddfa Cymru - National Museum Wales, U. K.Dec. 06, 2017----------------------------------‘Like the redwoods of California, China's Ginkgo's are ancient forest survivors that have always inspired awe for their beauty and longevity. What Jimmy Shen has also captured, though, are the charm and rich cultural history of these golden, graceful trees in their native land.’--Michael Brune, executive director of the Sierra Club,U.S.A., via Jim Bradbury, Communications Specialist, Sierra Club NationalDec. 20, 2017----------------------------------‘The book is very nice! I enjoyed it a lot, beautiful photos and interesting facts about this ancient and magnificent species. Liked the legends part, stories showing strong bondages between the tree and humans throughout the history.’--Ana Strbenac, Head of the Expertise Division at Croatian Agency for the Environment and Nature (ex SINP)，CroatiaFeb. 05, 2018----------------------------------Your book was astonishing, I believe that the ancient traditions linked to a plant species are one of the most interesting parts of our history. Also for this reason I want to thank the authors for sharing the wonderful images, the history and the interesting cultural connotations of Ginkgo biloba.--Alberto Giuntoli, PhD, Adjunct Professor at the University of Florence, Associated to the National Research Council of Italy, President of the Tuscan Society of HorticultureMar. 31, 2018  ----------------------------------It is impossible to pigeonhole this book into any one category. A sensitive blend of the sciences, humanities, and arts, a most remarkable tree is brought to life through spectacular photos and engaging text. At a time of so much biodiversity loss, I wish every species could have a Jimmy Shen, someone to tell its story with admiring words and inspiring images. I have always been fascinated by the Ginkgo. I now have many more reasons to be.--Quentin Wheeler, President, College of Environmental Science and Forestry, The Ohio State University, U.S.A.Apr. 04, 2018----------------------------------‘My first reaction is that your pictures are very beautiful indeed. I have seen a lot of photographs of Ginkgo - and taken many myself - but your images are really very special - and some (for example the fallen leaves with frost) are very unusual. Beautiful!’--Sir Peter Crane, FRS, President of the Oak Spring Garden Foundation, former Director of the Royal Botanic Gardens in Kew, London, former dean of the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies at Yale University.May 15, 2018----------------------------------"I have long been fascinated by the ancient Gingko since I first learned about it in forestry school. As a symbol of eternal life, I carry a Gingko leaf with me wherever I go to keep me safe and grounded to the Earth. I was delighted to have the opportunity to view Jimmy Shen's magnificent photo collection of ancient, old and young Gingko trees in their stunning natural environment. Jimmy has poured so much love and beauty into this wonderful creation and for that I am deeply grateful."--Scott Poynton, Founder, The Forest TrustMay 18, 2018 ----------------------------------‘This is a wonderful book on a wonderful plant with wonderful pictures! Congratulations. I look forward to the printed version.’--Koen Camelbeke, Executive Director at Arboretum Wespelaar, BelgiumJune 13, 2018----------------------------------‘Thank you for sending me virtual copy of your magnificent book of imperial quality. I hope your efforts of getting it published as you wish will be successful.’J.J. (Hans) Groenendijk, Senior Expert International Cooperation and Development, TISE Consultancy; Interim Chief Technical Advisor Natural Reserve of Ngiri Triangle Project (DRCongo), World Wildlife Fund, The Hague Area, NetherlandsJune 19, 2018----------------------------------‘It is indeed great to hear that all of your hard work and taking the comments of others into consideration to make the Gingko book the best it can be. Congratulations on the soon to be published edition. I know it takes a lot of work to visualize a project like this and persevere over time to make it a reality.’--James R. Shevock, Botany Research Associate, Fellow, California Academy of Sciences (CAS), the U.S.A.June 19, 2018----------------------------------'You must be delighted with the progress you have made with the Ginkgo book – it’s looking really good – a very smart production on a fascinating subject.'--Dr Mark Johnston MBE, FArborA (Hon), FCIHort, FICFor, Independent scholar: arboriculture, landscape and urban forestry, Based in Belfast, Northern IrelandJune 22, 2018----------------------------------'I am grateful to Jimmy Shen for sharing his passion with the world like this. Years of experience have done a beautiful job of showing these ancient trees, both close up and far away, as part of their natural environment. They are not the pristine specimens of carefully manicured botanic gardens, but their rugged natural state is no less impressive! This book will surely bring new appreciation of the species to many plant lovers.'-- Matt Borden, Doctor of Plant Medicine , University of Florida, U.S.A.July 16,2018----------------------------------By the way, I am honored to be featured at Global Diversity Foundation https://www.global-diversity.org/a-photographers-passion-for-a-living-fossil/... I am going to shoot a documentaryMy advisor, Prof. Shiyan Xing led a team of 100 plus professionals a few years ago, conducted field investigations on Ginkgo resources in China for a period of 3 years, and totaling over 62,138 miles/100,000 km. Based on the updated information, I am going to shoot a documentary. This time I am learning cinematography.And if you are interested to join the team, please contact me. Climb a high mountain to shoot an ancient Ginkgo; See these leaves shivering in the breeze... Where are these butterflies transformed from Ginkgo leaves flying?Find out in the book. Tell You a SecretWe all know male and female ginkgos are separate trees. There are no bees involved as go-betweens. How do Male and Female Ginkgos Date? In spring, pollen cones grow on male trees while the ovule develops on the females. Carried by the wind, pollen travels miles across hills and rivers, meanwhile the ovule sends out a drop of liquid on the top to catch pollen passing by.Get to know more about the story of wild Ginkgos? Download 100+ pages of the Ginkgo picture book, by clicking the link:  http://jmp.sh/6j2iXabor you could get the whole ebook of 320 pages for 5 dollars by claiming perks on the right. Discover and share wonders of Nature. Please spread this campaignI have no Facebook, Twitter, Youtube or Vimeo account, I am an internet dummy, besides no access to them here in China. Please spread this campaign with your friends in your social media or send to your email contacts who you think might be interested.Well, I have a linked-in account and have 17k contacts.  https://www.linkedin.com/in/ginkgo/  You could also meet me there.Discover and share wonders of Nature.

story:
About the Project

"The search for homeplace is the mythical search for the axis mundi, for a center, for some place to stand, for something to hang on to." -Lucy Lippard, from The Lure of the Local

Home, for me, will always be a 1200-acre farm in the Red River Valley of eastern North Dakota.  Its original 160 acres were homesteaded in 1884 by my great-great grandfather, a Norwegian immigrant.  My parents are now the fourth, and last, consecutive generation to work our land, as my siblings and I (like so many other young people) have all moved away to pursue other careers.  These circumstances provided me with the impetus to document our farm and its origins in Norway at this critical juncture.  I combine my images with materials from my family’s archive, such as documents and snapshots, to create a rich multi-layered narrative.  Just as different layers of texts intermingle on reused ancient manuscript pages, the history of our farm is marked again and again on the land as a palimpsest. As world populations shift from agrarian to urban lifestyles, our small family farm is only one amongst many that are approaching a crossroads.  What will happen to them?  Who will maintain these traditions and what does this tradition mean?

After six years of working on this photographic project, “Homeplace” will be published by Daylight in Fall 2013—my first book!  And because this is my first book, the publishers have asked that I cover part of the publishing costs.  I cannot raise these funds alone and am asking for your help.  Please donate and spread the word to make this book come to life!

Proposed Book Specs & Your Contributions:
Clothbound, hardcover book
Approximately 160 pages, with color and black and white photographs and scholarly texts
Size:  8x10 inches

Your contributions will help pay for the publishing costs, and in exchange I am offering a number of exciting rewards, including:

  • thank you postcards with an image from the book
  • mass-produced and hand-printed limited edition prints in a variety of sizes
  • signed and numbered copies of the book, available only through me
  • and a chance to commission me for a custom photograph!

Think of this campaign as a pre-publication sale.  By purchasing now, you have the chance to get one of the first 500 copies of the book and the same hand-printed, limited edition black and white gelatin silver prints as found in the collections of the National Museum of Photography in Copenhagen, Minot State University in North Dakota, the University of Iowa (Iowa City), and private collections throughout the United States, Denmark, and France.  Please note that shipping is included with all perks, as is a thank you on my website.

Any additional funds I raise will go towards upgrading the book, such as using a higher quality paper, different colored endsheets, etc. 

This book will allow me to share this important project with a wider audience.  I’ve chosen to work with Daylight, instead of self-publishing, because they are a respected publisher with a long history of supporting smart, conscientious, and socially engaged projects.  Plus, they have a distribution partnership with D.A.P. (Distributed Art Publishers), “the world’s top distributor of art books.” 

I know that not everyone can contribute financially--you can help by spreading the word & sharing my Indiegogo campaign with others.  I'm especially interested in generating greater interest via online, social, & print media.  I will also be accepting bulk orders of books for gifts or resale.  Please email me (sarah@sarahchristianson.com) for further information.  Also, don't hesitate to contact me if you would prefer to make an arrangement offline.  Any support that you can offer as I undertake this endeavor will be much appreciated!

About the Artist
Sarah Christianson (b. 1982) grew up on a four-generation family farm near Cummings, North Dakota. Immersed in that vast expanse of the Great Plains, she developed a strong affinity for the landscape and the stories it contains. This experience has had a profound effect on her work, as she enjoys creating narratives about place and personal experience through time, historical research, and the landscape. Her work has been exhibited internationally and can be found in the collections of several institutions in the Midwest and the National Museum of Photography in Copenhagen, Denmark. She received a BFA in photography at Minnesota State University Moorhead in 2005 and an MFA in photography from the University of Minnesota in 2009.  Since then, she has been living in the San Francisco Bay Area where she teaches photography at City College of San Francisco, volunteers at RayKo Photo Center, and remains an active member of the Society for Photographic Education.

For more information, please visit her website, and check out these interviews:

Interview with Chandler O'Leary of Anagram Press 

Family Pictures, University of Minnesota

Farming and Photographing, lesphotographes.com
